results.description:
If there is a single Beantown Gamers event you don't want to miss, IT'S STILL THIS ONE.  Welcome to our annual game night extravaganza -- the Holiday Party and Gift Swap!  At the party, you'll find:

• Tons of food and drinks
• Hordes of board games in two rooms
• Great people to play with
• A Double Board Game Raffle (tickets are free, just for showing up)
• The never-before-seen, one-of-a-kind, spectacular, amazing, One Night Ultimate Gift Swap

• Cost to attend: $3.00 (goes towards party supplies and site fees)


There is no cap on attendance for the Holiday Party!  All group members can attend.  However, accurate RSVPs are still required, so we can plan food and space use appropriately.

We have been fortunate enough to pick up an additional room for the evening.  That room is on the immediate right after you enter the building.  When you arrive, please head to that new room first to check in, drop off gifts for the gift swap, and pay the $3 entry fee.

Our regular room (which is larger) will be open for games (and snacks) all evening.  The small room will be used as follows:

7-8 Snacks and socializing
8-9 Gift swap and raffle
9-12 Open for games

We look forward to having a blast with you at the Game Night and the Party!  Now, read on if you want to be part of the...

ONE NIGHT ULTIMATE GIFT SWAP

What is it?  In a gift swap, everybody brings a gift; everybody opens a gift; and there are a number of chances for people to swap gifts.  It's basically a large, amusing, social game where everybody goes home with a prize.  This year's gift swap is going to be a ton of fun, as we're theming it after One Night Ultimate Werewolf, and there will be some Werewolf-inspired twists.  We also expect it to be our largest gift swap yet!  (And for those who remember last year's, there won't be any long chains, hehehe.)


If you plan to participate in the gift swap, please read these key details.

1. This year, we are stepping up our game!  We are looking for an approximate value range of $20 - $30, and we encourage you to bring gifts that are either:

• Board games (new or used, but in playable condition, please) or
• Board game accessories (like storage compartments)


Other items are also okay IF they are awesome.  Obviously that is subjective, but please, no more "Cruel Intentions" DVDs, bags of microwave popcorn, or bundled copies of Fluxx/Munchkin ;)  Ultimately, just bring something that somebody else will actually appreciate opening.  There will be an invaluable prize for whoever brings the best gift!

If you forget your gift, we will have several pre-wrapped gifts available to "buy in" to the gift swap at purchase price.  These will be available on a first come, first served basis.

2. Registration for the gift swap runs from 7:00 - 7:45.  If you arrive after 7:45, you will not be able to participate in the gift swap.  A lot of organization goes into it and there simply has to be a cutoff time.  Also, although we do not expect to even come close to running out of spaces, registration will also be on a first come, first served basis.  Please plan accordingly.

3. We expect the gift swap to take about 30 minutes and to be done before 9:00.  However, it may take longer if it is very large, and there is no absolute guarantee of when it will start and finish.  Please be forewarned of that if you have to leave by a certain time.

Thanks for reading!  It's going to be a truly awesome evening.  If you're looking for general info about our group, it's all below.

----

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us. 

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have a large crowd of regulars as well as new members each week.


BEANTOWN GAMERS RSVP POLICY:

1. Due to finite space, you must RSVP to attend.

2. Please be considerate of others -- only RSVP if you are likely to attend.

3. If you need to cancel your RSVP, please do so at least 24 hours before the event.  This allows enough notice for someone else to use your spot.

4. If you would like to come but there are no spots, consider attending our alternative "Light Game Night" a few steps away at Cosi Cafe.  You can also sign up as "wants a spot" and receive emails from meetup if a spot opens up.  Finally, if there are unusual circumstances, you can send Tucker a message.  (NOTE: DOES NOT APPLY FOR THIS DATE ONLY.)

5. We know everyone has emergencies.  But consistent, inconsiderate use of RSVPs -- which includes being a "no show", cancelling in the last 24 hours, or frequently cancelling RSVPs -- will lead to being removed from the group.  Sorry, we still like you, it's just not fair to everyone else!

6. If you use a "+1" spot, you are responsible for all of the above for your +1.  Since you are using two spots, it is extra important that you are considerate about it.

NEW MEMBERS: Welcome!  We look forward to meeting you.  If you want to bring a friend, please have them sign up with their own account rather than using a +1.  Unfortunately, we've gotten a lot of no-show +1's from first time attendees, so we don't accept those anymore.  Sorry!


We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle

As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

Update (10/15): In order to accommodate more people in the room, and maintain an easygoing environment for conversation and game playing, we ask that you please save loud games (like those with real-time arguing) for later in the evening, when the room is less full.  Typically this means 9:30 or later.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. Tonight only, there is a required fee of $3.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.
results.how_to_find_us: Walk a quarter of a block from the Kendall T, in the opposite direction from the Marriott Plaza. We're in the big building on your right (across from the parking lot). When you enter, our room is just across the foyer and on your right.

results.description:
Join the Boston Austrian Economics Group as we embark upon Chapter 9 & 10, of Part 2, in the Austrian classic; "Human Action: A Treatise on Economics," by Ludwig von Mises. The group will discuss the weekly readings and questions.

Please note that the readings are not required to attend our meeting, but are recommended. As always, anyone interested in economics is welcome.

Tony C's Sports Bar and Grill has plenty of parking and is accessible via the Orange Line "Assembly" stop. 

READINGS:

PART 2

Chapter 9: Action Within The World
Chapter 10: Human Society


QUESTIONS:

1) Why is it the always the individual who thinks?

2) What stimulates intellectual progress? 3) Why is it fallacious to believe that one group can only prosper at the expense of other groups?

4) What is a monetary crank?

5) To what does someone owe his might, and can minority rule endure?

6) What is the difference between an autistic and an interpersonal exchange?

7) Is echange a win-win situation?

8) Why does a contract imply mutuality?

9) Does a state imply hegemonic organization?

10) In what way did contractual relations help to form human civilization?

11) According to Mises, what does all action use?

12) Why is economic calculation so fundamental?
results.name: THE ROLE OF IDEAS AND EXCHANGE WITHIN SOCIETY

results.description: "I appeal to you, brothers, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that all of you agree, and that there be no divisions among you, but that you be united in the same mind and the same judgment."  Perhaps one of the most troubled churches we see in the New Testament while also being one of the most blessed, Corinth is an example of God's grace not to give up on a struggling church, as well as an example of how to be the church God wants.  1 (and 2!) Corinthians, Paul's back-to-back letters to the saints in Corinth, provide great insight into unity, maturity, church growth, humility, love, the resurrection, church discipline, salvation, faith, and a number of essential topics for those seeking God.  Come join us in our study of 1 Corinthians!

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.how_to_find_us: The third table in the middle of the climbing area between 7:00-7:10 PM. It's the table in the middle of the TR \/ Lead area.

results.description:
Here are just some of the things you can get out of these meetings:

• Access to thousands of dollars of courses, software, and other resources

• Advice on overcoming a business or marketing obstacle you're facing

• Accountability

• Ideas and inspiration

• Meet awesome people who enjoy talking about this stuff as much as you do

Or, you can be a fly on the wall.  No pressure at all.  Feel free to drop in to just listen and see what internet marketing really looks like from people who are actually doing it.

We try to keep the meetings to about 60 - 90 minutes.  Here's the way it works:

• 7:00pm Join the meeting here:  https://hangouts.google.com/call/dq4qhhdefftaq3fmqwij2ipe2ea.  It tends to work best with Chrome (rather than Internet Explorer or FireFox).

• Intros, and goal checking:

• New Members:  What are you working on?  And what is it you hope to get out of attending these meetings?

• Existing Members:  How'd your week go?  Did you accomplish your goals?  What are your goals for next week.

• Check-Up on last week's Couch of Insight participate:  What results did he/she get from the session?

• The Couch of Insight:  One member goes into depth on what they've been working on, telling us where they need assistance, what resources have helped them to be successful, and what strategies have been valuable.

• (Meeting Ends around 8pm officially, but usually runs late with people wanting to help the person on The Couch.)

• Chat and Offer Assistance: The Hangout will remain open until everyone leaves.  You can stay as long as you want to meet new members and give the person on The Couch any advice or feedback you may have.

Feedback

What's ONE thing that would have made this meeting better? Either let me know during the session, or you can keep it anonymous by filling out the a Survey Monkey (I'll provide the link in the session).

<a href="https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/KFNMRFX"></a>
results.how_to_find_us: Google Hangouts.  Join by clicking the link in the description.  Give it a shot before the meeting to make sure you can join without any problems.  Let me know if you're having trouble.
results.name: Weekly Remote Mastermind Session

results.description:
PLEASE NOTE: In anticipation of the Glass-Chewing Leader of the Cartel's imminent absence due to Family Growth, hosting duties for the regular Wednesday Night Gaming is being handled by a rotating cast of regulars.

Wednesday Night Gaming is our more-or-less weekly free-for-all of strategy gaming goodness downstairs at the Porter Square Panera. There's rarely a set agenda for these events but you are welcome and encouraged to hash out a plan beforehand in comments if you've got something you're dying to play. Nonetheless, you are not required to bring a game to play -- our only requirement is that you bring an open mind!

The event officially begins at 7 PM but people often trickle in early, so you're welcome to sit down to a filler game to get warmed up, or arrange to meet a little early if you've got a group looking to tackle an extra-meaty game.

Please be aware that Panera has been quite gracious about hosting us with minimal fuss -- in order to keep things this way, please respect the hardworking people who work there and, especially, their desire to get out after a long shift.

We'll see you at the gaming table!
results.name: Wednesday Gaming In Porter Square

results.description:
Let's talk about OpenStreetMap, the free crowd-sourced map of the world accessible to anyone. We'll give a brief overview of OpenStreetMap concepts and  and then spend some time editing or browsing the data.

Beginners are very welcome. Don't forget to bring a laptop. It's useful to bring a mouse if you have one when working with OSM data. 

If you've been contributing to OSM for years, come and lend your expertise to help others get started and answer questions. 

--------


Maptime is, rather literally, time for mapmaking. Our mission is to open the doors of cartographic possibility to anyone interested by creating a time and space for collaborative learning, exploration, and map creation using mapping tools and technologies.


This open learning environment for all levels and degrees of knowledge offers intentional support for the beginner. Maptime is simultaneously flexible and structured, creating space for workshops, ongoing projects with a shared goal, and independent/collaborative work time.


Inspiration for Maptime comes from both hack nights and knitting circles. Both are models of spaces for people to create and learn together. Our goal is to provide this space with an open heart and without pretension. You can bring your own projects to work on, or just hang out and socialize or ask questions. Some people are experts, and some people are just getting started, but all of us are learning, so why not do it together?


Maptime is hands-on, so don't forget to bring your laptop!
results.how_to_find_us: Show your ID to security when you enter 1 Broadway, then take the elevators to the 4th floor.
results.name: OpenStreetMap 101

results.description:
As the calendar year 2015 comes to a close, Let's take this opportunity to reflect. What wonderful things have you manifested, a new career, a published book, a loving child, a new perspective in life? All of you have given me such experiential gifts as I continue to grow as a facilitator and coach. It has been a wonderful year, and I can fondly recall many joyous moments.

What are your plans, as we move ahead towards 2016? I desire to awaken many more talented people to a wealth of healthy minds, bodies and happy souls by bringing in even more techniques to share with you. This group is about us, community and sharing our creative knowledge that means the New year involves you. What do you want to create, for yourself and for our community?

So, Let's Celebrate together.

Let's take some time to reflect our fun times together. Share some of our successful manifestations. Rejoice in the plans for next year, which include opportunities for you. Then, enjoy food and drinks.

Food will be provided. Feel free to bring a snack.

May you all have a happy & health holiday season filled

with love & gratitude

Ellen

results.description:
How can we increase our ability to create the life we want?  

To be in control of our life, we must first believe that we can control our life.  Yet we can sometimes hold beliefs that important areas of our life are outside of our control.  We play "have to", "should, or "victim".

To the extent that we lose our faith that we do have the power, we lose the power, and can not create what we want in our lives.

We will examine a few areas of our lives where we don't believe we have power, where we want more power, and where we want to create different results.  And we will reclaim our power.

We'll reprise one exercise from Insight, and we'll augment with a few additional exercises and insights from other sources. 

And we'll discuss the concept of "Create, Promote, or Allow".  

We will walk away with more power to create what we want (perhaps in this new year) in our lives.

About the Insight Practice Group
Insight Practice Groups are open to everyone -- to Insight graduates and to non-graduates alike. The only requirement is that you come ready to examine what a better life for yourself might be, and willing to do something to create it.

The Insight Practice Group is an open, informal gathering of like-hearted people who would like to explore, share, practice, and extend some of the lessons that Insight (not uniquely, but powerfully) introduces in their seminars. We reprise exercises, apply them to our current life, examine how to better put our results into practice, and augment the lessons with other sources of wisdom.

Disclaimer: These sessions are led by untrained volunteers like you, some of whom have taken Insight and some of whom have not.  Insight Practice Groups are inspired by, but not associated with, Insight Seminars.
results.name: IPG-128S: What If You Created, Promoted or Allowed EVERYTHING in your Life?

results.description:
This month, Eric McCorkle will be giving an introductory talk on denotational semantics.

Abstract:


Denotational semantics is a collection of powerful techniques that describe the behavior of a programming language by mapping terms to mathematical objects.  Aside from describing programming languages, these techniques can be adapted to many other uses, and many of the same concepts arise in other problem areas.  We saw an example of this last week in the talk on propagators with lattices and monotone function being an abstraction for many concrete problems.

While studying denotational semantics can be daunting, it tends to be much more accessible when the “big picture” view is known.  The aim of this talk is to walk through the concepts at a high level, with an emphasis on making the methods accessible to people without an advanced mathematical background.  I will give an overview of both Scott’s domain theory, as well as the more modern metric space methods, giving an overview of the theories with pointers for those who wish to dig deeper.


Logistics: 

If you can, please plan on arriving between 6:45pm and 7pm, but there will be someone in the lobby to greet stragglers.

Food:

Pizzas, salad and soda.

Afterwards:

If you'd like to stick around, a number of us tend to head down to the CBC or another pub afterwards to socialize. If you would like to give a talk or if you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to follow up here or email one of the organizers.
results.how_to_find_us: Simply come to the front door of Akamai. If you can, please plan on arriving between 6:45pm and 7pm, but there will be someone in the lobby to greet stragglers.
results.name: Eric McCorkle on Introductory Denotational Semantics

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

results.description:
The Public Open Night at the Observatory is a chance for people to come observe the night sky through telescopes and binoculars and see things they otherwise might not get to see, and learn some astronomy as well. The Open Nights are held most Wednesday evenings throughout the year, weather permitting.

It is open to everyone. Starting times are 7:30pm during the fall and winter, and 8:30pm during the spring and summer. The program lasts about an hour.

Weather

The weather is always a factor when observing. Unfortunately we can’t control the weather and we can’t observe when there are clouds, haze, or rain; so when the weather is bad, the Open Night will be canceled. Predicting the weather in New England isn’t easy, so we won’t know if the Open Night will be held or not until the day of the program. To find out if the Open Night will be held, call our information number at[masked], no earlier than two hours before the scheduled starting time. This lets us make the decision as late as possible while still giving those who live farther away time to get here.

Remember, it gets very cold in Boston in the winter and the telescopes are outside, so dress warmly.

>>> Tickets <<<

Public Open Nights are open to everyone, however space is limited. To reserve a ticket for admission click this link which will take you to our Eventbrite page.  [see website]

Location

The Public Open Night is held at the Coit Observatory at Boston University. We are located at 725 Commonwealth Ave. in Boston, right above the Astronomy Department. The stairwell to the Observatory is on the fifth floor right next to room 520.

Unfortunately, there is no disabled access to the Observatory.
Information

For information, please call[masked]-2630.

The Public Open Night at the Observatory is held clear Wednesday nights from 8:30 – 9:30pm. Call[masked] for the status.

Source: http://www.bu.edu/astronomy/events/public-open-night-at-the-observatory/
results.name: Public Open Night - Coit Observatory at Boston University

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]

results.name: Dance Freedom Steve and Chad

They are currently two times bachata world champions (2012 and 2013) and are the pioneers and ambassadors of the Sensual Bachata style leading into endless scenarios worldwide.

World Team Project (WTP) is a school and a network of dance professionals that brings to your city the style of one the world’s best artists , allowing you to improve yours while having fun in the trainning sessions focused in dancing the best choreographies in the world.

In two years, WTP has became the biggest dance network in the world and the only one that counts with the most renowned artists in each discipline, specially those dancing latin rithms like salsa, bachata or mambo.

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.

results.description:
This class is an opportunity to learn or continue your practice of Shamanic Journeying. You will "travel" to meet powers animals and other helpful teachers and guides through the practice of Shamanic Journeying. We will discuss the benefits and the process and then experience two journeys. To the lower world to meet a power animal or guardian spirit, to the upper world to meet a spiritual teacher or to the Middle World to connect to the hidden folk or an element in nature. The class will be catered to the needs and experience of the class.

Shamanic Journeying allows you to lift the veil between our 3D world and other dimensions. It is a wonderful way to get Divine guidance as well as healing from loving helpers who are waiting and eager to be of assistance.

Dress comfortably. Bring a journal or notebook, You may want a scarf or eye mask to cover your eyes to aid in going deeper into the journey.

Feel free to contact me if you have any questions prior to the class.

Price for workshop is $20. Please RSVP. Minimum of 3 people needed to hold this class. Bring a friend!


Wendy

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

Using guided relaxation, passive , active & visualization techniquesThis proven system is helpful for both the novice, looking to experience the benefits of meditation but are in need of assistance in achieving the desired outcome. As well as the adept wanting to go deeper into their meditation practice. 

Meet the teacher: 

Hi, I'm Shawna :D As a holistic health Practitioner of 15 years, I know first hand how the mind/body connection plays a significant role in ones health, relationships & personal satisfaction in life. I've found meditation & guided imagery as an incredibly valuable tool to assist students / clients in achieving lasting results. 

Some of the Many Benefits of Meditation:

Reduction of Stress, Tension & Pain (both physical and emotional)Clarity, Spontaneity & CreativityPeace of Mind & Well BeingEnhanced Energy Strength & VitalitySelf DiscoverySense of PurposeConnection to Inner GuidanceAlternative to Medication for ADHD and Other ConditionsImproves Focus & ConcentrationBuilds Self ConfidenceIncreases Serotonin (which aids in relief of depression, headaches & insomnia)

results.description:
Save the time and date:Thurday December 17,  2015, 12:30pm, somewhere in Arlington.


Remember when you worked in an office,and they gave you some time to eat lunch in the cafeteria, and  you actually pulled yourself away from your desk and went and ate lunch with other people?  

Nah, I don't remember that either, but it sure sounds like fun.  And, it's the law.  If your employer denied you a lunch break, you'd be filing a complaint with the state so fast.  

About 25 people expressed interest, which means that probably five to eight people will show up.  The others will all have good excuses, such as, "It's too cold," "I'm too tired," "I have too much work," "I have a deadline," "my clients need me," etc.  I don't want to hear your excuses, Please don't bore me with those lame-o excuses, I just want you to show up.

RSVP by obtaining a free ticket at eventrbire, first come, first served: 

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/collegial-lunch-for-people-who-work-at-home-in-arlingtonbelmontcambridge-thursday-1217-tickets-19816771497


 that way I'll know you're coming, and be able to contact you easily.  That will also help  to limit the attendance. If you think this idea can fly, please do sign up and show up, and then we can repeat this pleasure again next week. bests,

-rsr-

Ron Rothenberg

4Buyers RE

[masked]

Standards enable diverse technologies and companies to connect; just look at standard shipping containers or cable interfaces. They also ensure safety, such as food handling procedures. It's time to critically consider standards for robotics. Join us to hear from three speakers who each have a unique perspective on this topic. We'll hear about building designs that plan for integration with robots from Josh Ornstein. Adam Norton will discuss standard tests for robots that are being developed at the NERVE Center. And John Cross will speak about the US Army’s Interoperability Profile, which endeavors to create standard interfaces for UGV systems.

Rough agenda: 6 - 6:30: Networking and Pizza


(1) Josh Ornstein, CTO at Vecna

(2) Adam Norton, Manager at NERVE Center

(3) John Cross, Systems Engineer at iRobot 

7:20 - 7:30: 1 min pitches from audience. Need help? Looking for a job? Let us know. 7:30 on: More networking.

Parking is provided free by our host, Vecna.

results.description:
Transforming a product company to a connected product business.   

Join us for an insightful and interactive evening with real life practitioners of the Internet of Things (IoT) from LogMeIn's Xively product group and Avnet. The evening will start with the value created through IoT and connected products and then will shift to real-world examples of the IoT that are designed to a playbook others can follow for success.  We will cover current IoT ecosystem dynamics, accelerating companies’ time to market with IoT, and insights from early adopters on key challenges inhibiting scale. 

6:00 - 7:00 Networking, Introductions, Food and Refreshments 

Speakers:

Mario Finocchiaro, Senior Director Business Development IoT,  LogMeIn / Xively

Tim O’Keeffe, CEO of Symmons

Michael Hall, Account Manager, Avnet

7:00 - 7:45 IoT Business Case and Learning from Early Adopters

- Business Value of IoT, delivering a new view of your customer from the lens of your product

- IoT Land Grab, clarifying the key ecosystem players in IoT and defining example value chains

- Accelerating Time to Market, determining how to get a minimally viable product to market

- Product as a Service, new business models that will emerge from IoT

8:00 - 8:45 IoT in Action - Real-World IoT Demo and IoT Reference Implementation

- Tim O’Keeffe, CEO of Symmons, deploying IoT and transforming to a connected product business

- Deployed IoT product demo, the architecture and system integration

- IoT reference implementation, example IoT product that Xively team created in 3 weeks

- Getting started tools, we help you take that first step or to become an expert

8:45 Surveys and Raffle 


Speaker Bio: Mario Finocchiaro

As Senior Director of Business Development, Mario leads LogMeIn’s IoT partner ecosystem strategy and key customer engagements to drive the adoption of Xively’s IoT solutions.  Mario brings more than 20 years of global business development, sales, marketing, and management experience in enterprise software, telecommunications, semiconductor, and connected home.  Prior to LogMeIn, Mario held several leadership positions including Director of Business Development at Aware, Inc., Advisor to the BoD and Corporate Officer of HomeGrid Forum, and Director of Business Development at Axis Communications. Mario holds a BS from Babson College and MBA from Suffolk University.

Speaker Bio: Tim O’Keeffe

 Tim O’Keeffe, Chief Executive Officer, represents the third-generation of management for Symmons. In 2002, Tim began his career at Symmons in the technology department developing web and software programs for the company. After successfully implementing business software for Symmons, Tim moved to the Design Studio business, the company’s custom design service operation. During his management of the Design Studio business, Symmons created custom product for luxury hospitality properties across the country. Once the Design Studio program was operating successfully, Tim briefly managed the Marketing department before he was promoted to Executive Vice President. 

In his role as EVP, Tim was responsible for the day to day activities of the sales, operations, engineering and marketing departments.  In 2010, Tim was appointed Chief Executive Officer of Symmons Industries and leads the company in new business development, product innovation and strategic planning.

Tim holds a Bachelor of Arts degree from Bates College in Maine. He resides in Hingham, Massachusetts with this wife Sue and his two daughters. 

Speaker Bio: Mike Hall 

Account Manager for Avnet and President of Virtualization Group Boston. Mike Hall is a seasoned business professional and technology evangelist with over 25 years of management experience in companies ranging from Startups to Tech Titans. At Avnet, Mike focuses on accelerating business partners' success through a broad scope of system integration, software and supply-chain services and by connecting them with the world's leading technologies through the orchestration and delivery of cost-effective solutions and value-added services. Prior to Avnet, Mike held Sales Management and Marketing positions at Sony, Philips Electronics and Quest Software storage products divisions specializing in enterprise storage and virtualization solutions. Mike holds a BS degree in Computer Science and AS degree in Business Management through his studies at University of Maryland and Daniel Webster College, and served in the United States Army, NATO forces in Germany.
results.name: A Night of IoT with Xively by LogMeIn and Avnet

Sponsors:

Foley Hoag LLP - No industry moves faster or makes a bigger impact on the way we live than the technology industry. Technology innovators in software, hardware, gaming, entertainment and telecom turn to Foley Hoag LLP to help secure and maintain their leadership positions in this competitive industry. Our attorneys provide a comprehensive array of legal services for companies in all stages of development, from conception through profitability and beyond. For more information, please click here to visit our website for technology entrepreneurs. Follow @FoleyHoag and like them on facebook. www.FoleyHoag.com [masked]

What is FORGE? Autodesk’s Cloud based design and engineering app platform of the future (and now) connecting people that Design, Make and Use. The Autodesk program for partners building Cloud-based apps, with an intensive week of learning in San Francisco this June. Autodesk’s US$ 100 million dollar start-up investment fund. The Future of Making Things! Learn more at http://forge.autodesk.com and follow @adskForge.

Ministry of Supply - Inventing Apparel for Life's Work! Ministry of Supply is a menswear brand merging fit and function to create dress clothes as capable as they are comfortable. Launched out of MIT in 2012, the line includes dress shirts, chinos, blazers, and sweaters that wick moisture, regulate temperature, and move with your body. Visit our Boston store at 299 Newbury Street to experience the full collection in person. Can’t make it out? We offer Same Day Delivery in Cambridge and Boston, as well as a fully shoppable online store at www.MinistryOfSupply.com. Get 15% off Ministry of Supply orders during December, in store and online, using Discount code: MOSNewTech.

Mobinett Interactive specializes in strategy, design and development for mobile/web apps and backend software. Please contact us if you need any advice or help! Check out our "Top 10 Questions to Ask In Hiring a Mobile App Developer" and other helpful resources on the Mobinett Blog. Visit www.Mobinett.com, contact us here, or call <a>[masked]</a>. 


Products & Presenters:

1. Loud Bicycle / @LoudBicycle (Jonathan Lansey) - Make your ride safe with a bike horn that sounds like a car horn.

2. Prattle / @PrattleData (Evan Schnidman) - Text analytics firm provides data about central bank sentiment.


3. Freebird / @GetFreebird (Ethan Bernstein) - Empowers travelers to rebook on any airline for free after a flight disruption.


4. Wallflower Labs / @WallflowerLabs (Victor Jablokov) - Smart home device helps reduce the #1 cause of home fires - unattended cooking.


5. Zombait / @ZombaitLures (Matthew Borowski) - Technology meets fishing. Any other bait is dead in the water!

Agenda:


6:00 to 7:00 - Networking with dinner and drinks

7:00 to 7:10 - Announcements

7:10 to 8:30 - Presentations, Q&A

8:30 to 9:00 - More Networking

9:00 - More networking over drinks across the street, at The Whiskey Priest, 150 Northern Ave. (at Seaport Blvd.), Boston, MA. (optional)


Directions & Parking:


Foley Hoag is in the Seaport West building. Please bring identification and check in at our desk in the lobby. Type the last few letters of your last name on the screen or keyboard and once you see your name appear, tap on it to print your name tag. You'll also receive an access card to enter. Take an elevator to the 13th floor. Enter the glass doors and walk down the hall to your right.


Public Transportation:

Foley Hoag is in the Seaport West building, right next to the MBTA Silver line World Trade Center Station. Walk 1 block north on World Trade Center Ave and you will see the building on your left. You can also walk there in 15 minutes from the MBTA Red line South Station. 

Driving directions:

Use this https://maps.google.com/maps?ie%3DUTF8%26f%3Dd%26daddr%3DFoley%2BHoag%2BLLP,%2B155%2BSeaport%2BBlvd,%2BBoston,%2BMA%2B02210%26geocode%3DCZyPbW7oCbXSFWU1hgIdWfjD-yG1hpFfpE6UFg%26gl%3DUS%26hl%3Den">Google Map. There are parking meters along Congress St, Seaport Blvd, E Service Rd and Boston Wharf Rd and two open-air parking lots just east of the building (along E Service Rd), which charge $14-15 for the evening.

results.description:
Come celebrate Xamarin 4 with cake, pizza, and learn how to build, test, monitor, and accelerate native iOS and Android mobile app development in C#. Xamarin 4 was just announced including some amazing new features and enhancements including the all new Xamarin Mac Agent and Xamarin.Forms 2.0 for enterprise-grade mobile development, the brand new Test Recorder, and free crash reporting with the General Availability of Xamarin Insights. This month, we will take a look at all the new enhancements into iOS and Android Development in C# with Xamarin and all of the latest features that were just released. There will be something for everyone in this content packed meetup no matter if you are new or have been developing with Xamarin for some time.

Here are just a few topics that we will cover:

Xamarin.Forms 2.0: Xamarin developers have taken advantage of a shared business logic backend for years, but with the introduction of Xamarin.Forms it accelerate their cross-platform development introducing a shared user interface library and full MVVM Framework. Xamarin.Forms 2.0 takes advantage of the latest iOS 9 and Android Marshmallow features including material design, introduces several new gestures such as pull-to-refresh, rotate, pinch, and panning, as well as significant performance enhancements.

Xamarin Test Cloud & the Test Recorder: Xamarin developers are able to take advantage of their free Test Cloud time to test their applications on over 2,000 iOS and Android devices. We will take a look at the Test Cloud and see how the brand new Test Recorder simplifies the creation of complex tests to get you testing faster.

Xamarin Insights: Now generally available with completely free crash reporting for Xamarin developers giving you full native and managed crash reports and stack traces with just a single line of code! With a full cross-platform SDK you can easily report exceptions, track events, and gather additional information about the devices your app is running on.

So Much More: That is just the start! Xamarin 4 is packed full of even more features and enhancements that we will cover.
results.name: Xamarin 4! Everything you need to build great mobile apps

results.description:
We hear more and more about the "Dark Web" (or Deep Web) but most of us don't understand what that means. Join Benjamin Brown from Akamai and Will Lefevers of Constant Contact as they dig into anonymization networks and cybercrime. 


GRAB A TICKET! 


What are Anonymization Networks (Tor) and How do they Work?

Will will be presenting a technical overview of anonymization networks, how they work, and this whole "Darknet" thing everyone keeps talking about. Examples will be based on the most popular anonymization network today, Tor. Like any good security talk, design and implementation flaws will be discussed, as well as established techniques for de-anonymizing users and sites. 


About Will Lefevers:

Will Lefevers is the Lead Information 

Sec

urity Architect for Constant Contact. His 15 years of InfoSec experience includes military tours in satellite operations, counterintelligence, cyber operations, and vulnerability research. His foci include insider threat detection, behavioral analysis, malware reverse-engineering, and hunting threat actors in live networks. He’s also an avid homebrewer and writes exceptionally mediocre code. 


Cashing out in Cybercrime

The hardest part of cybercrime is the cashout. The strategy for cashing out needs to be easy enough to make it worth your while and safe enough to stay out of the klink. With more and more focus on identifying and stopping credit card fraud cybercrooks are diversifying their methods for cashing out. While criminals can, and do, sell whole and bundled online retailer accounts, credit card data, and fullz, I want to look at how they get their grubby paws on that cold hard cash. Lets dig into the tools, techniques, and procedures used by this new generation of e-launderers and cyber hustlers.

Understanding the lifecycle of a financially motivated cybercrime is an important part of successfully and efficiently defending against them. When we have insight into the tools, techniques, procedures, motivations, methods, and ecosystems driving these attacks we are afforded the opportunity to build defense in depth that specifically targets the weaknesses and load-bearing assumptions of the attackers.

About Benjamin Brown:

Benjamin Brown currently works on systems safety, adversarial resilience, and threat intelligence at Akamai Technologies. He has experience in the non-profit, academic, and corporate worlds as well as degrees in both Anthropology and International Studies. Research interests include novel and side-channel attack vectors, radio systems, the psychology and anthropology of information security, metacognitive techniques, threat actor profiling, intelligence analysis, and thinking about security as an ecology of complex systems.
results.name: A Journey into the Dark Web

results.description:
The winter holidays bring about the opportunity to gather with family and friends. Engaging with people we care deeply about on topics that can seem controversial - like race - is often met with a lot of resistance.  In fact, it is one of the challenges that comes up most frequently at our accountability sessions.  As the saying goes, "Never talk religion or politics at the dinner table."  But if we hope to change the climate of white supremacy in this country, gatherings with loved ones are a great place to start. 


Join us to share your experiences, ideas, and support as we navigate the challenges and strategies for moving these conversations forward.

We will be meeting in the library of the YWCA in Cambridge - use the Bishop Allen entrance if you are able to use stairs.

Use the Temple St entrance and call[masked] when you arrive if you need elevator access.  (Or connect with us prior to the event if you don't have a cell phone.)  You will have to contact us to be let in from this side--we won't hear the bell.  Sorry for the inconvenience.
results.name: Home for the Holidays?  Family conversations about racism

Every Thursday evening at 6:30 PM we gather as a group for a nice nighttime "romp" at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir. It's a great way to wind down a busy work day, to catch up with Bulldogs friends, or to meet new people!

The Boston Bulldogs is a co-ed non-profit running club founded to support those battling addiction and in recovery, those who have been affected by addiction and their supporters.

We welcome and encourage runners of all levels – dreamers, beginners, as well as those with running experience, past or present. Our volunteer runners will be there to coach you at your current level, and help you meet your goals. We might even be able to help with running gear if needed. 

We meet twice weekly at the Reservoir (Cleveland Circle/Reservoir Green Line C or D train) -- on Saturday mornings at 10:00 am and Thursday evenings at 6:30 pm. We will first gather in front of the Starbucks in Cleveland Circle, before heading over to the reservoir. See you there! 

If you are interested in becoming a member or a volunteer, in making a contribution to the Club, in sponsoring a runner in recovery, or in learning more about the Boston Bulldog educational wellness/running program, contact us at:

• Website - BostonBulldogsRunning.com

• Email - [masked] 

• Phone -[masked]

results.description:
"A universal theology is impossible, but a universal experience is not only possible but necessary. It is this experience toward which the course is directed." (ACIM Manual for Teachers)

Designed to correct perception and lead to a universal experience of knowledge, A Course In Miracles has been translated into 23 languages, is referenced and utilized by many of today's most reknowned spiritual teachers, and has inspired countless books and curriculums based on its teachings. But it can be a difficult book to grasp. It is lengthy, the writing is abstract, and its use of Christian terminology alienates many.

And yet it has become one of the most influential spiritual books of today. Join us as we dive into it, and are led to understand its principles against the backdrop of our own personal experiences and insights. Beginner as well as advanced Course students are welcome. We'll start with a short meditation, and then use a reading from the Course as an entry point into our time together. Cost $5 per person.

Bringing a copy of the book is helpful, but not necessary. Recommended (but again not necessary) is the combined volume that includes the three supplements (Clarification of Terms; Psychotherapy: Purpose, Process, and Practice; The Song of Prayer), available online from The Foundation For Inner Peace at acim.org.
results.how_to_find_us: From Concord St.: we're 4/10th's of a mile down Russell St. on the right, the driveway after Fraser Farm.
results.name: Join us as we discuss A Course In Miracles and apply its principles to our lives

results.description:
Deepening into the practice of Speaking Circle turns will support you in continuing  to develop full presence in front of groups.  Being in Relational Presence with your audience is the key.

Relational Presence, the foundation of Speaking Circles, is a precondition for all masterful communication. When this state becomes your default mode of approaching every communication, you effortlessly step into a natural flow. 

Developing your capacity for Relational Presence is like strengthening a muscle that has been neglected. Unlike the struggle that physical workouts are for many, this exercise is designed to be highly pleasurable. There may be some initial confusion, discomfort, self-doubt but hang in there and do the reps no matter how it feels or what you are thinking.  With practice you will find . . . 

* Speaking Circles support you to access your natural public presence, along with your capacity to unselfconsciously express passion and purpose.

* Reach hearts, minds and souls every time through the practice of being in a Speaking Circle.

* Transmit your message and content with ease to groups of any size by practicing attunement with one listener at a time.

* Give up conventional notions of "public speaking" and discover the magic of authentic intimacy with audiences.

results.name: Deepening into Speaking From Presence

results.description:
SEASON OF LIGHT EVENING PRESENTATION

“…the body itself is a screen, to shield and partially reveal the light blazing inside your presence,” Rumi.

Each December, various faiths and traditions exalt the transcendent power of light as a spiritual principle that illuminates, clarifies, and unites. Center for Spiritual Living Greater Boston is proud to sponsor our fourth annual Season of Light-A Holiday Celebration. This evening’s presentation weaves a tapestry of 7 cultural, diverse spiritual traditions and faiths that focus upon the many gifts of LIGHT. The founder of Centers for Spiritual Living, Dr. Ernest Holmes, states: “We are not going through a harder time today, a longer or darker night, than has ever been experienced before. It only seems darker because we have lost faith—the beacon light. If one will have faith, in himself, faith in his fellowmen, in the Universe, and in God, that faith will light the place in which he finds himself, and by the light of this faith, he will be able to see that ALL IS GOOD.”

Come and join us in sharing beautiful music, poetry, rituals, and camaraderie of this magical, inspiring, and heartwarming event! All are welcome.

This gift to the community, will take place on Thursday, December 17, 2015 from 7:00 pm. to 8:30 p.m. at First Church Boston, 66 Marlborough St., Boston.

Any questions, please call Reverends Ed Tanzi and George Stewart at[masked]-2743.
results.name: SEASON OF LIGHT-A HOLIDAY CELEBRATION

group.name: Center for Spiritual Living Boston Teaching Chapter

results.description:
The sharing of gifts is the essence of holiday celebrations. When gifts come to mind, we usually think of material things. But gifts can go far beyond possessions. They can include the greatest strengths of character that we have to offer the world, unique life experiences we have to tell, lessons we have learned about ourselves and the world around us, etc. They can even come masked in traumatic events - like in our separations, divorces and lives as single parents. Finding the diamonds in our dilemmas in the essence of transformation.

Let's do this in a unique way at this year's Trauma to Transformation Holiday Party. After all, divorce and single parenting are constant invitations to embrace life in new ways...

Come to give the following:

-the gift of your presence to others...
-your favorite holiday treat...
-and a thought to share on the following:

"What is the diamond inside your divorce and life as a single parent, the gift inside the grief?" It could be ANYTHING, from the freedom to explore a new hobby on your own, to a creative capacity to cuss continually, to having a better relationship with your child... Hey...we are all in different place on this journey, right? Sharing is optional.

Come to receive the following:

-the gift of the presence of others...
-others' favorite holiday treats...
-new perspectives on the diamonds others find in their divorces and lives as single parents...
-AND an opportunity to laugh, share, enjoy, and celebrate what is during this holiday season. And to just come as you are... Holiday cheer encouraged, but not required!

Drinks, appetizers and treats will be provided.

This event will be held at gracious Fatemeh's office space in Needham. Address below.
results.how_to_find_us: First Parish is in Needham Center, near the intersection of Great Plain Ave. and Dedham Ave. and Highland Ave.  Park behind the parish.  Enter the building on Lincoln St. Go down the stairs and to the right.
results.name: Trauma to Transformation Holiday Party - Let's Celebrate As We Are...

results.description:
And a happy holiday!

Come and join us for a great evening of crafting, hanging out, eating great food and swapping presents/yarn.

Sarah has kindly offered up her apartment and so the event will take place at hers in Brighton.

To make it as great as the previous years, please bring some sort of snack/potluck/cookie item, and of course it's BYOB! If you're worried about doubling up on the snacks, feel free to comment below what you're bringing!

SWAP SPECIFICS!

COOKIE SWAP!

Bring a dozen (or more) cookies and be prepared with a bag or some kind of receptacle to take some with you home. Feel free to comment on what cookies you're thinking of to ensure we won't all be coming home with one kind ;)

YARN SWAP!

Have some yarn that is just taking up space in your stash? Want to exchange yarn for some other color/weight? Bring any/all you want to get rid of or exchange! 

YANKEE SWAP!
Previous years have been GREAT successes! Here are the rules: Bring a gift that is ~$10 wrapped and once everyone has arrived, we will be drawing numbers. #1 goes first and so on. The catch? If say, #2 likes #1's present more than their own, they can exchange it. Knitting or general interest things are suggested as the gift!

Looking forward to seeing you all there!
results.name: We knit you a Merry Xmas

results.description:
Itadaki downstairs bar (Boston, Newbury St. between Gloucester and Fairfield) 7 pm to 10 pm

Join me at this izakaya style venue for a pleasant evening of drinks, food and chats. Whether you're learning Japanese or English, buy a drink, join the table, and practice your new language in a friendly and relaxed environment. If you're a beginner or just interested in culture, you'll fit in fine! Don't miss out on this opportunity to learn and practice over a few drinks. Can't make it on time? Need to leave early? Not a problem. Just stop by if you can!

If you are >21 and plan to drink, please bring a MA state issued ID or passport. Other state IDs may not be accepted. Please order at the bar and take care of your own tab.

Transportation: I highly recommend using public transportation. Not only is driving while intoxicated dangerous, but there may not be any parking available in the area. A lot of the parking on Newbury St  is Residential Only in the evenings, and many of the signs indicating this are very well hidden. If you insist on parking in the area, be aware that meter maids love handing out parking tickets around here. Best methods for public transportation are the green line subway or bus #1 to the Hynes stop.

I have made an arrangements with the Itadaki staff for a simpler ordering method. Last time was very chaotic and stressful for the bartender, so lets do our best to not confuse the bartender. :)

Ordering at Itadaki

1) Order your first drink at the bar. If it's alcoholic, your ID will be checked at this time. You will also be  given a guest number to use the rest of the night.

2) If you're at a table, the bartender will try to make several rounds throughout the night to take additional orders. Keep using your guest number and please feel free to order more food and drinks.

3) Keep in mind we're a pretty large group so don't be offended or annoyed with the bartender if he doesn't get to you right away. If you have an urgent order, go request it at the bar.

4) Please take care of your tab and don't forget to tip*. The management and staff are doing a lot to make this all possible.

*Note: If the group is large, an 18% tip may already be included.

See you there!
~Lindsay
results.how_to_find_us: Go to the downstairs bar and look for the sign!
results.name: Backbay Japanese Evening Table

results.description:
Ongoing class in 18th & 19th century Saber, developed from Scottish Broadsword and Smallsword, as well as 19th century Saber sources.

The Broadsword is the archetypal weapon of the Highlander swordsman - a broad-bladed cutting and thrusting weapon. It has a basket hilt to protect the hand and wielded single-handed.

The Smallsword is the courtly weapon of the Scottish warrior class. An elegant thrusting weapon it teaches the fighter to use the thrust and make small parries. The smallsword is the immediate predecessor to modern epee.

The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.

All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.
results.name: Historical Saber

results.description:
This monthly Meetup is a place to learn tunes and to play them slowly with other musicians. The tunes we play can be found here (Sheet Music). Since the list is getting large we have started selecting a rotating list of about ten tunes a month that we will definitely play so that new members can have a chance to play along without learning every tune right away. I update this list and email it monthly.

This is still a new group, and how we go about learning and playing is still a work in progress. But the goal is to have fun, and to get together with others who enjoy playing Irish music. Musicians of all levels are welcome. Since the goal here is for everyone to play, new members are encouraged to suggest tunes from the list and to suggest tunes to add to it. If the group as a whole knows a tune well, we'll play it slowly a couple of times, and then pick the tempo up a bit. 

Note on tempo

If you have gone to a typical Irish Session, we play a little faster than half that speed. But we'll start tunes slowly enough that everyone should be able to play along and learn by ear. If you haven't been to a session it is best to just show up and see if the tempo suits you :)  If you like metronomes...  For Reels (4/4), Hornpipes (4/4) and Polkas (2/4) set the metronome from 100 to 140 BPM and play one quarter note per click. For Double Jigs (6/8), Slip Jigs (9/8), and Single Jigs (12/8) set the metronome from 65 to 95 BPM and play three eighth notes per click. 

Directions

By Subway

The closest Red Line stop is Davis Square. From Davis Square you can either walk Northwest on Holland Street or take the bus (the 87 or the 88) to Teele Square. It is about a 10 minute walk between Davis and Teele Square. You can recognize Teele Square as a 5-way intersection with a small triangular island having a sign that says Teele Square. From Teele Square walk North on Curtiss Street for 3 blocks to Powder House Boulevard. The church is on the NE corner of the intersection.

By Bus

The 87, 88, and 89 buses stop in Teele Square.  The 87 bus runs between Lechmere Station (Green Line) and Arlington Center. The 88 bus runs between Lechmere Station (Green Line) and the Clarendon Hill Busway. The 89 bus runs between Sullivan Square (Orange Line) and the Clarendon Hill Busway. You'll want to get off the bus in Teele Square. From Teele Square walk North on Curtiss Street for 3 blocks to Powder House Boulevard. The church is on the NE corner of the intersection. The 77 bus runs between Harvard and Arlington Heights. You can walk from Mass Ave to Teele Square.

By Car

There is parking behind the West Somerville School that is one block West of the church. Parking there is available after 5PM even though the signs are somewhat ambiguous. From Powderhouse, turn onto Curtis, heading up the hill toward Tufts. Take the first left turn from Curtis onto Raymond Street. Ignore the NO LEFT TURN sign, as it is only in effect during rush hours. Raymond runs behind the school. The lot is about half a block down Raymond on the left.

Street parking is also available one block away on Packard Avenue from Powderhouse Blvd on the hill to the Tufts University campus. Pay attention to street signs to avoid parking in a restricted area.

See the map at: http://clarendonhillchurch.org/...

Accessibility

The church has a lift that requires someone to move from a wheelchair to the chair on the lift. I haven't had time to look at this yet, but I will have someone show it to me over the holidays.

results.description: FRAGS (FRAmingham GamerS) meets at my house in Framingham on Thursdays. I have been running this event for over 30 years. I have hundreds of games, a full-size pool table, and 15-seat movie theater for PS3 games including BUZZ and ROCK BAND, in addition to movies. results.description: Mike Lemme and Chris Post present this monthly showcase featuring talented comedians, musicians and poets inside one of Cambridge's most unique venues, Gallery263. The name, Off Mic! refers to the fact that Gallery 263 is so intimate, amplification is often totally unnecessary. Without a microphone, the barrier between performer and audience is knocked down. Off-Mic! gives audience members a behind-the-scenes look at the creative process of performing. TICKETS: Suggested donation of $10 at the door Purchase yours now : http://gallery263.com/event/off-mic-comedy-spoken-word-and-music/

Mister Bismuth! Osama Bin Reagan! Herb Marple! Adam Abelson! Kate Procyshyn! HELL YES!

It's our pleasure to introduce HERB MARPLE: He's 74 years old....
he's just had his 3rd stomach surgery, this week.
he's vice president of the Natick rotary club,
it's his first time doing stand up.... 

Herb Marple! NEXT: it's OSAMA BIN REAGAN. Your favorite fictional punk-a-pella band returns, filled with misplaced rage and a love of kitties and puppies. Join Obese Bruce and Danny Decay for a weird-ass set you have to see to believe.

THEN YOUR HEADLINER: Mister Bismuth is a sketch comedy group that aims to make you laugh, while at the same time trying to make you laugh. If necessary: by force. Mister Bismuth. Comedy is our element.

PLUS: your host for the evening is the incomparable satirist, character creator, and all-around hilarious human Adam Abelson! ALSO: Special Guest Star Kate Procyshyn, described recently at the Women in Comedy Festival as the Lady Paul Bunyan of Boston Comedy! Get weird with this killer night of comedy, and it's all for you!

results.description:
Last Week Tonight's Josh Gondelman will record his new live album at this month's edition of Strange Behavior, a stand-up comedy show hosted by Ryan Donahue at the historic Davis Square Theatre. Come spend a Thursday evening with one of NYC's top comedians as he performs with Sean Sullivan (Comedy Central) in this intimate 175-seat blackbox theatre! For tix and info: http://bit.ly/1I8XUqE


Josh Gondelman Bio: Josh Gondelman is a writer and comedian who incubated in Boston before moving to New York City. Onstage, Josh charms audiences using his good-natured storytelling and cracks them up with his sharp, pointy wit. Offstage, Josh is a writer for Last Week Tonight with John Oliver on HBO and the co-author (along with Joe Berkowitz) of the book You Blew It, available now from Plume. He is also the co-creator and co-author of the popular Modern Seinfeld Twitter account.

In the past, Josh has written for Fuse TV’s Billy On The Street. His writing has also appeared in prestigious publications such as McSweeney’s Internet Tendency, New York Magazine, and The New Yorker. Additionally, Josh has performed at the Rooftop Comedy Festival in Aspen, CO, and headlined at the Laugh Your Asheville Off Festival in Asheville, NC. More recently he has appeared in the Eugene Mirman Comedy Festival, the Bridgetown Comedy Festival, and SF Sketchfest. His debut standup comedy CD, “Everything’s The Best” was released in November of 2011 by Rooftop Comedy Productions.

For more information:

www.facebook.com/strangebehaviorcomedy
www.davissquaretheatre.com
results.name: Josh Gondelman's Live Album Recording!

results.description:
December 18, 2015

Learn How Employees, Customers and Vendors Saved Market Basket at North Shore Business Forum’s Meeting on Friday, December 18, 2015.

Featured Speaker: Grant Welker, Author of “We Are Market Basket”

Grant Welker, is a journalist at the Lowell Sun and co-author of the book We Are Market Basket: The Story of the Unlikely Grassroots Movement That Saved a Beloved Business. Welker will expand on the fight by employees, customers and vendors to save the Market Basket supermarket chain, which became an inspiring national story that also offers business lessons, showing that a company can do things differently and still be successful.

About the Speaker: Grant Welker covers the city of Lowell, Massachusetts, for the Lowell Sun, where he has worked since 2012. He was previously a reporter at the Herald News in Fall River, MA, and has worked in journalism for nearly 10 years. His coverage of the Market Basket story included about 80 news articles for the Sun, earning him two New England Newspaper & Press Association business reporting awards. He has also been recognized by the New England Newspaper & Press Association for prior reporting on education, social issues, crime, transportation and the environment. Grant has a bachelor’s in journalism from the University of Connecticut and lives in Boston with his wife, Angela. To contact Grant, email: [masked] .
results.name: Market Basket:Learn How Employees, Customers and Vendors Saved a Beloved Company
