results.description:
Hi Urban Sketchers,

Let's head to the Harvard Museum of Natural History to sketch! The Harvard Museum of Natural History was created in 1998 as the “public face” of three research museums — the Museum of Comparative Zoology, the Harvard Mineralogical and Geological Museum, and the Harvard University Herbaria (I did not know this was a word).

 It hosts a variety of natural world exhibitions, including a large glass flower collection. The museum is on the Harvard University campus and is the school's most visited attraction. 

The details for this event: The museum entrance is free before 12:00PM for all Massachusetts residents with proof of residency so bring your state ID (or rental agreement?). Otherwise the museum is $10 for students and $12 for adults. If you have a Harvard ID, are a Harvard Museums member, a teacher, an ASTC passport program member, or apart of active duty military, the entrance is also free. 

Drawing is encouraged in the galleries, but the use of clay, paints, pastels, and chalk is not permitted. So bring your pens, pencils and colored pencils! I think that about covers it, hope to see you there!
results.how_to_find_us: Meet in the lobby of the museum and be sure to get your free admission ticket first!
results.name: Let's Sketch! The Harvard Museum of Natural History

results.description:
Come join us at our regular Scrabble Meetup, and play over lunch or a pastry and some coffee!

We meet twice a month, every month, on the first and third Sunday. Please bring a board if you have one. We have a few spares, so you are welcome to come even if you forget your board.

Newcomers are always welcome. We keep 2 and 3 letter "cheat sheets" for new folks to keep the playing field more even.

We mostly play Scrabble one-on-one, and pairing is random. If you would like to be matched up to someone of a similar skill, just let the organizer know.

Au Bon Pain is right next to the Davis Square T stop, and there is typically ample free street parking on Sundays.  A few times a year, there is a race in Davis Square that shuts down some streets, so keep an eye out for that. If possible I will send out a message to the group the day before.

$1/Meetup goes to help pay for the annual Meetup.com dues and miscellaneous photocopying, but if you are a regular $10/year will be easier for you and me to keep track of!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the people with Scrabble boards out--the cafe is usually empty on Sundays.

results.description:
Last month's Walk Off the Turkey Hike was such a great time that many of us asked to do it again which is why Hike 4 Life scheduled a Scavenger Hunt Hike.

Hike4Life is excited to be closing the year with their first Geocaching event.


What is Geocaching? Geocaching is a real-world, outdoor treasure hunting game using GPS-enabled devices (cell phones). Participants navigate to a specific set of GPS coordinates and then attempt to find the geocache (container) hidden at that location. If you take something from the geocache (or "cache"), leave something of equal or greater value. Write about your find/experience in the cache logbook through the app and/or at www.geocaching.com

Meet Up in the Blue Hills Trailside Museum parking lot 12PM!!!


BEFORE we hit the TRAIL you MUST Download the "GEOCACHING" app to your Android or iPhone. The icon is on the flyer!


https://www.geocaching.com/mobile/default.aspx


If you have any questions about the hike and/or geocaching

contact Jrel of Hike 4 Life via (617)[masked] or [masked]

Here's a checklist for a safe and fun time...

Attitude - A Positive One
Backpack - To carry your food, water, extra pair of socks and any of your trash.
Boots - Keeps ankles stable when stepping on rocks
Camera - Capture Memories
Clothing - Wear layers
Grub - Suggest Beef or Turkey jerky, granola bars, fruits such as apples, oranges, bananas or grapes. Gum, sunflower seeds, crackers, trail mix.
Head Cover - Hat, Bandana, Scarf
Water - At least 2 liters. It's better than sports drinks.

While this is FREE please consider supporting Hike4Life with a donation.

Hike4Life 42 Howard Avenue Boston, MA 02125

For updates regarding weather advisories, check 'Geocaching w/ Hike4Life' Facebook event page from this link https://www.facebook.com/events/893013740795248/


((RAIN/SNOW DATE: 12/27/15 in Franklin Park))


By Car: Take Rt I-93 to exit 2B (Milton, Rt 138 North). Follow the exit ramp to the first set of traffic lights. Go straight through the lights and the parking lot is 0.5 miles ahead on the right. The museum is at the end of the parking lot.

Public Transportation:

MBTA: Red Line (Ashmont Line) to Ashmont Station.  Connect with Mattapan High Speed Line to Mattapan Square. Then you will need to take a taxi because there isn't any Sunday bus service.

Comment on here if you need a ride or are able to offer a ride.
results.name: Scavenger Hunt with Hike4Life Sunday December 20, 2015

Holly Days Open House takes place over three days to stop by and  share some festive cheer enjoying light refreshments. Visitors will be able to tour the festively decorated mansion, and participate in recipe and craft making activities! The open house is free & open to the public.

COST:  Free

The event offers a great opportunity for anybody who has not visited the estate before!  It is a beautiful Victorian red brick mansion set atop Osgood Hill in North Andover. Placed on the National Register of Historic Places, The Stevens Estate is one of the few remaining grand estates of the Victorian era in North America.

Holly Days Open House Weekend is the first Open House at the Stevens Estate under new director, Joanna Ouellette. The Stevens Estate is owned by the Town of North Andover

results.description:
Why Feminism? Why Now?: The Importance of Being a Feminist Today – And Why It’s So Hard to Do So
Feminism is often defined as simply “the advocacy of women’s rights on the grounds of political, social, and economic equality to men,” but it’s so much more complicated than that. Let’s talk about what feminism really is (and isn’t) and what makes being a feminist today so hard.
Melissa A. Fabello is a sexuality and media literacy educator and body acceptance and eating disorder activist based in Philadelphia. She currently works as Managing Editor of Everyday Feminism and is a doctoral candidate in Human Sexuality Studies at Widener University.

With special musical guest Magen Tracy.
results.name: Melissa Fabello: Why Feminism? Why Now?

results.description:
** UPDATED - DECEMBER 20 **


18xx games are about railroads: building track and running trains for profit. 18xx games are also about a stock market, and the skullduggery between various robber barons as they try to build, thwart, take over, or bankrupt companies. But, they can take quite a while to play. We play with poker chips and emphasize a "ready to play" culture (meaning you're ready to act when your company is up). Games have generally taken from 2 hours (via bankruptcy) to 6 hours (to the end) with the average around 5 hours, even with new players. The more you plan in advance, the faster the game (of course, many times the other robber barons thwart your plans!)

You will need to be ready to start right at the starting time, or very close to it, because the game is so long. We also are splitting into two games quite frequently now so being early is better so we can decide which 18xx games to play and then have to set them up, unless we ALL can come to a pre-arrangement in the comments.

New players are welcome although we strongly suggest familiarizing yourself with the basic rules and concepts first. A brand new player will need 20 to 40 minutes of rules explanation before they play. The game really isn't overly complex, rules-wise, it's just long with lots of decisions. It is a little fiddly sometimes, though.

Due to some late arrivals in prior months, we will emphasize: If you're over 15 minutes late and have not made arrangements with one of the tables, you are probably only going to be a mere spectator, unless there is a game doing a rules explanation, you know that 18xx variant well, and can make it before it starts. If you're much later you probably won't be able to join a game at all. It usually takes us all afternoon and well into the evening to play one game of 18xx. Even our more "experienced" tables usually drop four or five hours into a single game (or more; last month we didn't finish either 1835 or 1830 until 9:30 PM or later). It is rare that there is a second game.

Also since we usually know the people in the week or so prior it will be good at that point if we can sort out what games we want to play in advance. While it's no guarantee we can break down that way, knowing to set up something in advance is SUPER helpful and time saving. Setting up and teaching a new 18xx variant can take an hour or more and the games are quite long as it is, so every little bit helps. What you need to know about 334 Mass Ave:

-Press 999 on the intercom and security will let you into the building
-You must sign in at the security desk with a picture ID
-Take the elevator down to level "A." Exit the elevator to your left and the community room will be ahead on your right, next to the laundry room.
results.how_to_find_us: Press 999 on the intercom and security will let you into the building, sign in with picture ID, take elevator to level "A." Exit elevator down corridor to the left; room will be on the right (to the right of the laundry room, on the corner)

Groups are wonderful! They help bolster your commitment and motivation, they supply you with opportunities to get ahead on your journey, and they provide support from the other members.
But when it comes to EFT, groups are even more wonderful! Not only is there a synergy created between the tappers increasing the potency of healing received, but even when the tapping isn't related to your particular problem, you still bet to borrow benefits from it!

Note that the amount of people allowed in the tapping circle is limited to 10. If you need to cancel your reservation, please do so at least 3 days in advance so that someone else can come in to the event...

Please arrive early. Doors will open 15 minutes ahead of time and the tapping circle will begin promptly at 2 pm. Late comers will not be allowed in. A late arrival not only disrupts the flow of the circle, shatters the feeling of safety so necessary in healing work, but can also prevent the facilitator from pacing the circle well.

Fee: $20 in advance, $25 at the door.

See you soon!

results.description:
For our next book, we have chosen another classic in the world of investing:

A Random Walk Down Wall Street, written by Burton Malkiel

We are going to be reading the 1st chapter for this next meeting. Hopefully, anyone interested in reading along with us will have enough time to borrow or purchase a copy of the book.

Please feel free to join us even if you don't choose to read the book. We use the book as a framework for discussion, but we always branch off into other investing topics as well.

Here is a nice description from Goodreads:


"Using the dot-com crash as an object lesson in how not to manage your portfolio, here is the best-selling, gimmick-free, irreverent, vastly informative guide to navigating the turbulence of the market and managing investments with confidence.

A Random Walk Down Wall Street is well established as a staple of the business shelf, the first book any investor should read before taking the plunge and starting a portfolio. With its life-cycle guide to investing, it matches the needs of investors at any age bracket. Burton G. Malkiel shows how to analyze the potential returns, not only for stocks and bonds but also for the full range of investment opportunities, from money market accounts and real estate investment trusts to insurance, home ownership, and tangible assets like gold and collectibles.

Whether you want to verse yourself in the ways of the market before talking to a broker or follow Malkiel's easy steps to managing your own portfolio, this book remains the best investing guide money can buy."


http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/900892.A_Random_Walk_Down_Wall_Street

results.description:
We heard an author describe this tragedy in Salem recently.


That IMAX showing is sold out, so I've switched the venue.  I know the seats are crazy, but we do want to be able to get in.  This is the 3D show time.


In the winter of 1820, the New England whaling ship Essex was assaulted by something no one could believe: a whale of mammoth size and will, and an almost human sense of vengeance. The real-life maritime disaster would inspire Herman Melville’s Moby-Dick. But that told only half the story. “In the Heart of the Sea” reveals the encounter’s harrowing aftermath, as the ship’s surviving crew is pushed to their limits and forced to do the unthinkable to stay alive. Braving storms, starvation, panic and despair, the men will call into question their deepest beliefs, from the value of their lives to the morality of their trade, as their captain searches for direction on the open sea and his first mate still seeks to bring the great whale down.

Starring: Chris Hemsworth, Cillian Murphy, and Brendan Gleeson
Rated PG-13: for intense sequences of action and peril, brief startling violence, and thematic.

results.name: Let's see In the Heart of the Sea

results.description:
Christmas in the City strives to ameliorate the impact of being homeless on families and children living in shelters towards a goal of eliminating homelessness. Christmas in the City does all of this with 100% volunteers. They have no paid staff.

More than 3,000 homeless children attend the annual Christmas in the City holiday bash every year, where they were treated with gifts, a seven-course meal, and loads of games and activities.

We will be helping make the party flow smoothly. We will be assigned to an area to help out and will also help escort guests to waiting transportation.

Party Helpers will also prepare Jake’s Toy Room to distribute gifts to thousands of children on behalf of Christmas in the City.

This is a great way to give back around the holidays and work with such an incredible organization that enriches the lives of homeless children everyday. Hope everyone can make it!
results.name: Party Helpers at Christmas in the City

results.description:
(Almost) Tis the season to be jolly- and also giving!

To celebrate the gift of friendship, why not partake in a little gift exchange shortly before the holiday? All you have to do is bring a wrapped present $10 or less with your name on it, and prepare yourself for a surprise gift at the conclusion of a game!

Come one, come all. Bring snacks, a friend (if spots are available!), mistletoe, or your favorite Christmas sweater! Seriously though, snacks are always appreciated =)
results.name: Finding Pedro Gift Exchange!

results.description:
Join the Fresh Pond Walking Community for our regular Sunday walk around Fresh Pond.   

Let's join regular walkers from surrounding towns + members of five other walking groups and 20+ walkers for this walk.  Walk is on, Rain or Shine.

Few things are more enjoyable than a nice walk and a chat at the end of a busy weekend.

Since May 2012, we've met with a few other meetup groups Let's join for a stroll in a beautiful setting.

We walk clockwise, so if you get there late, just start walking counter-clockwise and you'll run into us.

Parking on Huron Avenue is easy, since the "Permit Parking" rules don't apply on Sunday - just park in any spot on Huron Ave, there will be plenty of them.

If you're coming by bus, take the 71 or 73 bus from Harvard Square and get off at Aberdeen Ave. Walk all the way up Aberdeen until you come to Huron Avenue, we'll be there.

Afterwards, we'll go out for dinner. We usually go for some unusual Chinese food, and the total cost is about $10 per person.

If you have trouble finding us, call me at[masked]

results.description:
Join The Oldest Established Permanent Floating Community Walk in Cambridge 

For the 200th consecutive Sunday, we will be walking.   Let's join 20 or so others from other walking groups for this walk.

The walk is on, rain or shine.


Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.


Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

We'll all go out for dinner afterwards, somewhere in the neighborhood.

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

WHAT: ASL Weekly Social
WHEN: EVERY SUNDAY 
TIME: 4:00-6:00PM
WHO: ANYONE is welcome to come by and have a conversation in ASL
WHY: To socialize, have fun, and enjoy chatting in ASL
WHERE:  Panera Bread in Porter Square Shopping Center

NOTE: Every once a while, the location may change. PLEASE look on the website each week for confirmation. THANKS!


To get to the Meetup, take the RED LINE stop OUTBOUND TO ALEWIFE, and stop at PORTER SQ. Panera Bread is right next to Dunkin Donuts. If you're driving, you can park on the street for free on Sundays!

Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

Don't be afraid or shy if you're not "perfect" at ASL, because being "perfect" is not the point of this group. No one expects that everyone will be at the same level, and none of us mind slowing down or repeating what we have signed so that everyone understands.

We all laugh WITH one another as we fumble along, mess things up, and start over again. This isn't an ASL class, since none of us are certified ASL teachers, so there's really no pressure or expectation--other than that we all use ASL to communicate. We all learn from one another!

IF you've taken an ASL/Sign Language class before (or have had exposure to someone who uses the language) and know the basics (alphabet, numbers 1-20, and even a small vocabulary of signs ), then join us to get your fingers, hands, face and body moving, ASL-style!

IF you haven't taken an ASL class, or don't know the basics, don't be discouraged ... you can come along anyway and learn by watching, and gradually, participating. We have lots of resources that we can suggest for learning ASL from a qualified teacher or authentic source, such as books, online classes, and local classes at various locations near Boston.

If you can, "officially" RSVP, even if the RSVP is "No," so that we know who is definitely going to come.

It will be great to see folks!

Sean
results.how_to_find_us: We will be there signing our beautiful language to inspire all of you!
results.name: ASL WEEKLY SOCIAL

results.description:
Boston is all decked out for the holiday season with more lights than ever. In this workshop we will focus on the three key skills necessary for night photography. The weather looks clear for Sunday so lets get out there and enjoy the magical beauty of the night. 


Trees wrapped in lights.Working with positive and negative spaces for creative composition and dramatic impact.

Some of the topics we will cover in the program:

1. How to get the proper camera settings to capture the stunning lights against the dramatic night sky. 

2. How to  composition to balance the different zones of the image using creative strategies including and beyond the rule of thirds.

3. How to work  with reflections of lights in water and windows to add depth and mystery to your images.

We will photograph a range of subjects including trees, architecture, and people. 

You do need a tripod for this workshop since we will be experimenting with show shutter speeds. You don't need to know how to set your shutter speed, I will help you.

Surreal colors of the night sky. 

The warm weather means they have not yet drained the water from the pond in the Boston Gardens so this allows for some really stunning photos of reflections. I took this one just now with my iPhone but can't wait to go back and try it again with my camera.

Architecture and blur motion capture. Beautiful contradiction of stillness and motion. Join us to learn what settings to use. 

Abstract images using slow shutter speed to capture light.

Experiment with dramatic perspectives and view points.

If this sounds like fun, I hope you will join us for what will probably be the last workshop of the year. Knowing how to photography night scenes is an essential skill to add to your knowledge base as a growing photographer so I hope you will join us.  Take a break from the holiday stress and enjoy the beauty of a night out in Boston!  I am limiting this program to 12.

Hope to see you on Sunday! 

Suzanne

Trees at night magical quality captured with available light.

results.description:
Give yourself the gift of relaxation and rejuvenation with a wonderful 90 minute gentle yoga and meditation class.

True relaxation is experienced by the body and mind when little or no energy is consumed. It is Nature's way of recharging. Since every action, conscious or unconscious, uses stored energy, relaxation is necessary for good health and peace of mind. Without proper relaxation the body and mind become overworked and inefficient.

When the mind is constantly bombarded by stimuli, it becomes overloaded and exhausted. We may be unaware that we are doing it, but by thinking and worrying we are using up tremendous amounts of energy. The tension put on the mind by worries can use more energy than physical work.

Yoga retrains the body to relax and can calm the mind which leads to inner peace.

This class is for beginners and experienced yogi's.  Chairs are available for those who may need to sit during this class.  Please bring your own yoga mat, water and a blanket or pillow for meditation.
results.name: Gentle Yoga & Meditation - 90 minute class

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

https://2015bostonatwysspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.
results.name: Speeddating  Ages 38-48 -1F/3M spots left

results.description:
This is a TWO-PART EVENT, a two-day fine art sale (Saturday and Sunday) and a concert (Sunday). The description is longish, but worth the read. FOR THE CONCERT, AS SPACE IS LIMITED, RESERVATIONS ARE REQUIRED,  http://www.eventbrite.com/o/notlob-music-6730833315. THE MIRASI COLLECTIVE concert has  a direct connection to Boston Cultural Nomads; if you attended the Association for Central Asian Civilizations & Silk Road Studies two weeks ago you saw this brilliant ensemble. Now is your chance to combine fine art viewing with a concert.

In collaboration with Villa Giuliana - Atelier, notloB Music is proud to present THE MIRASI COLLECTIVE


"Dear friends, Come to this year's last art & music celebrations in my studio and of my American life. This is the last opportunity to bring home a token of me and to be together in the homy space I have created at Miller Street Studios in the last 15 years. I will open the doors on Saturday by appointment* and Sunday from 11 am through 5pm, with a 7 pm special music in-house concert**. Details follow on this page. I will also be available in my studio. Contact me by personal message or PM notloB Music if you can't make on Sunday. Let's bridge the gap and be all together!!! Alessandra"

FINE ART, BOOKS, JEWLERY, CLOTHING AND COLLECTABLES SALES

*Saturday by appointment - call[masked]
Sunday 11am - 5pm.

After the closing to the public of Sunday's sale, Alessandra's studio will be opened at 6pm for a private showing to all attending the concert.

THE MIRASI COLLECTIVE

**Sunday, December 20, 2015

Private studio show for concert guests – 6pm

Concert – 7pm

Suggested donation $5-10, cash.

Reservations via Eventbrite are REQUIRED - http://www.eventbrite.com/o/notlob-music-6730833315
(will be ready Tuesday, 12/15).

THE VENUE

Miller Street Artist Studios

11 Miller Street, Somerville (near Porter Square).

By foot – From Porter Square T, walk down Somerville Ave to Beacon Street. Miller Street will be on your left.

By wheeled transport – Miller Street is off Beacon. As both concerts are on Sundays, park in any legal space on Miller or Beacon, but please avoid the nearby Star Market lot and the caterer’s lot.

CONCERT DETAILS

·  Admission is by free-will donation.

·  As everything in the studio, including furniture, is for sale, there is no guarantee there will be sofas or chairs, so please bring seating / floor pillows / yoga mats. On the other side of the coin, this means there will be more space for dancing on the beautiful wood floors.

·  BYO food and beverages.

Due to limited space, reservations via Eventbrite are being taken. Anyone arriving at the studio without a reservation will be seated only if in the mind of the studio owner there is sufficient space.


https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-mirasi-collective-tickets-20029806691

THE MIRASI COLLECTIVE


www.facebook.com/themirasicollective/ 
The Mirasi Collective is a Boston-base group that swings hard- exploring the boundaries of South Asian music while preserving its beautiful traditions.
Artists: 
Sonny Lalchandani 
Is a recent graduate of the New England Conservatory and performs both Sitar and Sarod in his band SkiM and in solo formats.
Sarvesh Varma
Is a Tabla player, trained under his guru Pandit Kiran Deshpande, and Ustad Zakir Hussain, and has performed in India, Canada and USA.
Michael Dwan Singh
Is a multifaceted artist, audio engineer and a producer who excels at playing Sarangi; learning under the lineage of the late Ustad Sultan Khan.Is a multifaceted artist, audio engineer and a producer who excels at playing Sarangi; learning under the lineage of the late Ustad Sultan Khan.

-----------------
* Come to the sale and/or the concert, but if you wish to attend the concert you MUST SIGN UP IN EVENTBRITE! Those not holding Eventbrite reservations will only be seated if, in the opinion of the studio owner, there is adequate space.

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

https://2015bostonatwysspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

results.name: Karaoke

results.description:
There will be a stimulus for each meeting to inspire the conversation. The stimulus can be anything, such as a picture, a short story, a breaking news, etc. Each meeting includes stimulus introduction, small group and whole group discussion, and personal reflection. Every attendee is encouraged (actually required) to raise questions inspired by the stimulus. And then we will discuss why these questions are important; how these questions relate to one's personal life experience; what is one's perspectives on these questions, and how the discussion might affect one's future thinking.

This is a place to share our souls and learn from others, NOT a place to promote any particular school of thoughts, beliefs, faiths, political views, etc. We must keep an open mind, respect each other, and agree to disagree.

Meeting Agenda: 7pm-9pm

1. Get your coffee and introduce yourselves: 10-15 minutes

2. Introduce the stimulus: 5 minutes

3. Small team discussion: 15 minutes

• What soulful question do you want to ask?

• Why is this question relevant/important to you?

• Vote on the question to submit to the whole group.

4. Group discussion: 45-60 minutes

• Each team submits a soulful question and explain why this question is relevant/important.

• Vote on which question to discuss within the whole group.

• In depth group discussion on the chosen question. The conversations should be related to one’s personal experience.

5. Individual reflection: 10 minutes

• What is your takeaway from today’s discussion?

• How will it affect your future thinking?

6. Conclusion and plan for next meeting: 5 minutes

Recap of previous meetup

11/15/2015 Six soul searchers attended today’s meetup.  We had a very lively and personal discussion tonight.

Three stimuli were provided in this meetup, which can be found in the photo album:

Afghan widows struggle to survive the long shadow of war. After decades of conflict, many women are struggling on their own to care for themselves and their children.

Robin Williams’s widow Susan Schneider Williams points to undiagnosed Dementia as a suicide cause. Susan was Robin’s third wife. She recently settled a legal dispute over Williams’s estate with his three children by his first two wives.

A matrilineal society called “Kingdom of Daughters” still exists today in a lakeside village in southwestern China.  This society’s official name is Mosuo, a minority ethnic group with a population of about 40,000.  The foundation of Mosuo culture is a centuries-old practice of walking marriage, in which men visit women at night to fulfill the need for procreation and sexual gratification.  Traditionally, a Mosuo woman might have several walking marriage relationships during her life, sometimes simultaneously.  Children take their mothers’ surnames and daughters are preferred to sons.

Many great questions were raised by soul searchers.  The group’s favorite question for tonight was: “What is love? - what does it take to make and keep a happy/fair relationship?”

Other questions include:

How to define power within a relationship? What does the “ideal” relationships look like between male/female lifetime mates for each each of us? What is the value of a man/woman relationship? Life is so fragile and uncertain, yet we live so much in the future. Why?  What is the balance of now vs. later? Can one be happy alone without a companion? Why is it difficult for a group to welcome a new person into their circle, when the initial impression of the new person is not exciting? Is there a life after widowhood? Will co-housing work for single older people? Why hasn’t the matrilineal culture spread? When is life not worth living? What is considered fair in a love relationship? How to live with loved ones who are suffering severe mental illness? What about the way cultures have evolved given the contrast of women in Afghanistan vs. Chinese matrilineal society.

results.description:
It's week 13 of the 2015 Liquid Courage Comedy Club at Somerville Brewing. FREE: The comedy club experience is called the Liquid Courage Comedy Club at Somerville Brewing Company. The brewery and destination-taproom, which opened in April of 2105, opens Sunday nights as a showcase style stand-up comedy club open to the public 21+ with no cover charge or ticket fee. Guests are able to order charcuterie boards, dinner and pints during, before and after the show. With a Sunday night show time of 9PM there is ample free parking is available.

Season 1, the 2015 dates are as follows: September 13th, 20th and 27th, October 4th, 11th and 25th, November 1st 8th 15th and 22nd December 6th 13th 20th and 27th.

The opening night on September 6th filled to capacity and guests were entertained by 7 professional comedians and show host C.J. Browne. “We’re excited to offer a curated show of experienced local comedians. Since the room and setup require excellence the showcase is not an open mic night. We are absolutely psyched about the success of opening night. We played to a full house that loved the show.” Show performer Gary Peterson says “The Slumbrew comedy show was such a fun room to work, because the owners care about making it fun. A packed house of young heroes supporting the local scene makes this place special. It makes me happy to know something so cool is alive in Somerville.”

results.description:
This is a friendly monthly reminder to contribute $11 yearly to help us pay off the yearly Meetup Group fee and additional cost to run the group and keep the group going. This is more for member's information and is not meant to sound that I am angry. Also, note that  Biagio is NOT getting rich from the group fees.  This is a YEARLY fee and NOT a monthly fee.

I wanted to address any crazy rumors and incorrect assumptions that I am getting rich from Meetup. These assumptions are based on having ALL 9,000 members paying the $10 a member fee which would equal $90,000, but that is 100% incorrect. I am not making $90,000 a year for this group!

So please let me clarify less than 1% of the group’ members actually pay the $11 yearly Voluntarily Donation. Out of that $11 PayPal take their cut so I only get  $10 per member. I barley take in $200 a year and that is NOT enough cover the yearly Meetup fees and the other Meetup expense like printing out Meetup materials, supplies for the group, batteries, games, Meetup business cards, etc. Over the past 6 years I've acquired over $2000 of debt to run this group and cover Meetup expenses. So it is time to understand the truth and stop making assumption.

Biagio is pretty Poor and Not rich. Luckily, there hasn’t yet been a need for me to start to begging for money on the side of the street……….. yet!

I am now paying Meetup a $200  fee  every year to run the group. In 2015 we have only collected $150 from members for the Meetup Group Fee so far, and we have not paid off the 2014 debt which is over $500 now. If we cannot get members to pay off the 2014 and 2015 debt  then I’m just going to let the group shut down due to lack of  funding when the 2016 payment is due.

Don’t forget,  I pay for batteries, supplies,  printouts,  signs, games, stands  etc. etc. to run this group its over $700 a year,  which includes the $200 a year Meetup fee!

So please be informed and realize what it takes to run a group this large. Oh and add to that I spend 30+ hours every week of my own time running the group which I get paid $0 for.

Please help keep the group going. Don’t let not giving $11 a year, every year stop all the fun. Oh and you don’t have to pay the $11 online you can pay the $10 in person or e-mail me to pay by check.

If you want to pay online Meetup has shut down the Amazon payment feature so you can now pay using Paypal and pay $11 to my PayPal account using e-mail address which is [masked]

</a>

<a href="mailto:[masked]">===================================

With PayPal, you can send money to anyone with an email address.

Here’s how to send money:

Log in to your PayPal account.


Click Send money to a friend at the top of the page.

Type the email address or mobile number to whom you are sending money, and the amount being sent. In this case its [masked]

Click Next.  

Review and confirm the information on the screen and click Send.

=======================================

Thanks and let’s keep the fun gong!

Biagio

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Monday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
Save the time and date:Monday, December 21,  2015, 12:30pm, somewhere in Belmont..


Remember when you worked in an office,and they gave you some time to eat lunch in the cafeteria, and  you actually pulled yourself away from your desk and went and ate lunch with other people?  

Nah, I don't remember that either, but it sure sounds like fun.  And, it's the law.  If your employer denied you a lunch break, you'd be filing a complaint with the state so fast.  

About 25 people expressed interest, which means that probably five to eight people will show up.  The others will all have good excuses, such as, "It's too cold," "I'm too tired," "I have too much work," "I have a deadline," "my clients need me," etc.  I don't want to hear your excuses, Please don't bore me with those lame-o excuses, I just want you to show up.

RSVP by obtaining a free ticket at eventrbire, first come, first served: 

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/monday-collegial-lunch-for-people-who-work-at-home-in-arlingtonbelmontcambridge-tickets-19956653889


 that way I'll know you're coming, and be able to contact you easily.  That will also help  to limit the attendance. If you think this idea can fly, please do sign up and show up, and then we can repeat this pleasure again next week. bests,

-rsr-

Ron Rothenberg

4Buyers RE

PLEASE RSVP SO WE CAN CONFIRM WE HAVE NUMBERS FOR THE GAME.


6:30-6:45 pm - Warm up & practice, we'll work on some throws, passes & catches.

6:45 pm - Game starts.

General guidelines: Dress accordingly. Bring a white & dark shirt so we can easily divide into 2 teams. Have plenty of water. Sunscreen on a sunny day. Stretch & warm up. We'll provide discs and cones.

Weather: Rain in New England is unpredictable. We will send out a final notice one hour before start time if cancellation is necessary.

RSVP: Very helpful as this is how we contact you in case of game changes & cancellations.

About: Playing Ultimate is all about good sportsmanship, respect, and gracefulness on the field.  Fun & having a good time is a must above anything else. It's an easy game to pick up & we keep the rules minimal. No zones, no stall count, no scores, and players self-officiate on the field.  Open to all levels of players.  Beginners welcome.

Warning: Excessive fun & comradery developed from playing Ultimate may become addicting.

results.description:
Yes, this will be our last HackNight of the YEAR!! So, we hope that you can all make it out. We will be getting into the holiday spirit, and giving out a couple of gifts too. So hope to see you all there!


Bring any Android project you like, weather you are currently working on a side project as a hobby, have a new startup idea you want to work on, or just getting started on some tuts, and interested in learning more about Android in general! This is a good way to learn among your peers, network, meet some new people, get some help or feedback, and maybe even collaborate on a project together. So bring your energy, passion to learn, and most importantly bring your selves... 

The event will be graciously hosted by Raizlabs..


Raizlabs is not new to mobile, and have been around since 2003, getting started right here in Boston. They have worked to build a reputation for one of the premiere mobile shops in Boston. 100 launches later, Raizlabs currently has locations both in San Francisco (2013), and Boston. Previously Raizlabs was located in Coolidge Corner, then downtown Boston as 2012, and expanded to a larger venue earlier this year. If you have not checked out the space, this your chance, it really is a great space. We are are thankful to Raizlabs for hosting our next event!!

Agenda: 

6:00p-6:15p- Doors open, networking, and beverages provided. Brief welcome, announcements, and getting started with HackNight. 

6:15p-7:30p- Hack on some projects. 

7:30p-7:45p- Q&A session if needed. Check-in, and continue hacking.. 

8:30p-9p- Keep hacking, 8th inning stretch around 8:30ish. Wrap-up, and closing words at quarter of 9..
results.name: Last HackNight of the YEAR!!

results.description:
Discover the holistic benefits of the Feldenkrais Method®!

Each 90 minute Awareness Through Movement class consists of guided attention through carefully sequenced movements that are designed to stimulate your curiosity, challenge your coordination, and bring you into a new way of being in both body and mind. 

By encouraging us to slow down, reduce effort, and delve into the building blocks of our movement, Feldenkrais Awareness Through Movement enables us to discover previously unnoticed areas of habitual tension and unlock new possibilities for moving freely. Come and experience for yourself what an effective resource it can be for stress relief, improving balance and posture, and alleviating chronic pain at the source. 

Classes are open to adults at all fitness levels. No prior experience necessary. Drop-ins are welcome, but RSVPing will give you the opportunity to influence the content of the class for your needs and interests! 


Dress comfortably and bring a yoga or pilates mat. We have a few extra available.
results.name: Feldenkrais Awareness Through Movement class!

ABOUT:  This service, held on the longest night of the year, is a remembrance service for those who are grieving or struggling and need to hear the hope and promise of Christmas, after a death or in the midst of a medical or emotional struggle. * It is also for  those who find themselves ALONE during this time.  The biblical story of Christmas is told in the context of gentle music and candlelight with time designated for silent reflection. More info can be found at: www.main-street-church.org

TIME: 7pm  ( meet up time is earlier - to meet and get seating)

* PLEASE NOTE: This meet up was created in the hopes that anyone of ANY faith may find some solace on this evening, and during holiday time. It is non denominational, and does not reflect the views, beliefs, religious or otherwise of the meet up group. It is in no way meant to be offensive to anyone in anyway.  

* As always, if the weather is questionable, please check for any updates/comments prior to heading out
results.name: 'BLUE CHRISTMAS" Amesbury

results.description:
Please come and join us for a pleasant evening of competitive party bridge in Panera Bread, located in the Fresh Pond mall, about a 10 minute walk from Alewife station. The more the merrier, so long as you know how to play.

This meetup is officially canceled unless at least five sign up by 5pm. We can still play with four if we re-confirm. Check this space at 5pm if quorum questions exist. Out of courtesy, please do not sign up casually, nor cancel out on the day of event except in emergencies.

You must know Contract Bridge rules and basic bidding to play this week. No formal training is to be offered, but this is a social, casual event. To assist novices, bidding advice and meanings will be openly discussed on any player's request.

ACBL Yellow Card is our group-standard bidding system; a novice should please take time to study all basic openings and responses shown above in yellow, plus standard Jacoby Transfer and Stayman responses to NT openings. We will expect a verbal alert on deviations an expert may make to these most-common conventions.

results.description:
New:

Due to time constraints and the game being very adjustable to new players joining and leaving at any time, I am making a change.

I do wish people to get something to compensate IHOP for letting us use the space, however, if you have not started or finished eating by 7:15pm please, start or finish eating at another table. The rest of the people will clean the table and start playing.  I want the rest of the players to have a chance to finish a game.


The rules give new players the opportunity to join the game at the start of any new hand, with the score of the mean player.

I am trying to keep the game and conversation balanced for everyone.  If multiple players are eating, conversing and playing,  the game may be held up until some people are restless.

Also, the more people eating and playing while handling the cards, the greater chance the few decks of "Jumbo Index" cards used for Negation Hearts will be marked and hard to shuffle, detracting from the game.

As always, please put your cold drinks on a napkin.

Thank you;

Negation Hearts Night. New players are VERY welcome: We will teach you how to play.

It is suggested that you get a drink or something else there, to compensate the hosting establishment. .

PUBLIC:

Both: The 450 and 456 Buses have nearby stops. 

Negation Hearts is played with two decks of cards. Two of the same cards like two king of clubs negate and the next highest card of the suit lead takes the cards played. So, even playing a two has not been safe at times. The scoring and passing are slightly altered from "Cancellation" hearts so that new people can join in or leave at the start of any hand.

The 50 cent charge is totally voluntary and is only to approximately cover the meetup charge.

This is SOCIAL CARDS conversation is encouraged, however please be aware of when it is your turn to play a card, we try to keep the fun balanced between the two.
results.name: Negation Hearts in Salem @ IHOP *

results.description:
This will be the fourth session of our new Current Events meetup series (*no prior attendance is required!). We aim to have reoccurring discussions moving forward so we can stay abreast of local, national, and global anti-racism issues both as individuals and together as a community. We have seen a huge surge in media coverage within the racial justice movement over the past year. It can get overwhelming trying to keep up with all the stories, events, anniversaries, policies, and debates that touch on racial justice in some way. Let's pool our collective knowledge and discuss what's going on - locally, nationally, and globally - within the realm of anti-racism. This will be a great opportunity to share our sources, our stories, and our knowledge to keep everyone informed of the way things are changing, and unfortunately, the many ways in which things are staying the same.

The topics will change from month to month depending upon what's happening in the world, but many stories may carry over. Have a current event you'd like to discuss at the meeting that isn't listed below? Have a helpful article you'd like to share? Want to look at a story from an unexplored angle? Know of a local story/action/event that may not be getting coverage? Great! Feel free to post in the comments section below or email one of the facilitators with your ideas. We hope you'll come to this session willing to share a current event you've learned about over the past month or so. If not, feel free to come and listen, learn, and participate in some really important discussions. Looking forward to seeing you all there and kicking off this new series! 

Possible December Current Events:

-Donald Trump & Islamophobia 

- Chicago Police Department

- Campus Racism: Princeton, Mizzou protests/football team, president resignation, Yale


- Syrian Refugee Crisis

Review from November:


- BLM Minneapolis rally shooting

- Paris/Beirut Attacks

- Syrian Refugee Crisis

results.description:
Hello Ladies!

The book for December is Between the World and Me by Ta-Nehisi Coates. Since it's the holiday season, we will also be doing a cookie swap! Essentially the rules are as follows:

1) You don't have to participate if you don't want to. If you don't want to participate you must post on the event message board when you RSVP by writing - "No I will not be participating in the cookie swap." We still want you there even if you aren't bringing cookies!

2) If you do plan on participating you MUST declare your cookie swap item and ANY or ZERO food allergies on the event board when you RSVP - example posts would look like "Yes I plan on bringing chocolate chip cookies and I am allergic to peanuts" or "Yes I plan on bringing raspberry tarts and I am not allergic to any foods." That being said, please no duplicate desserts.  

3) Cookie swappers should plan to give 6 of their dessert items to each participant. So if 15 people participate including myself then I must bake 84 cookies for the day of the swap (15-1[myself]=14 then 14x6=84).

4) If you sign up to participate you really MUST try your best to remember your item the day of the event.


3) This is a "cookie" swap but that doesn't mean it has to be a cookie; it could also be a brownie, a tart, a bar, a type of fudge, a thing-a-ma-bob...anything as long as it is easily swapped and is a type of dessert.

4) It would be great if participants could bring copies of their recipe with them to hand out to others, but it is not required.

5) December 18th at 7pm is the cut off date/time for this meetup so that cookie swap participants can easily identify how many people will be involved in the swap (All participants will receive a reminder email for how many items to make).

6) If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to ask! 

We are very excited for this event and can't wait to try all the delicious desserts!! Hope you can make it!

results.description:
For our June meeting we will continue to discuss Common Core.

Common Core - we are in the thick of it! We will discuss the current and future of the fight, and what we can do. We will talk about the hearings at Bridgewater State University, which hopefully a number of us attended.

Governor Baker has directed Paul Sagan the Massachusetts Board of Education Chair to hold a series of public hearings around the state, which will solicit feedback from educators, parents, students and local officials on the PARCC exam and the real-world impact of Common Core standards on teaching and learning. The dates and locations are as follows. This is our opportunity to let our voices be heard.

The next hearing is Monday, June 22, 2015, North Shore Community College – Lynn Campus, Gymnasium, 4:00–7:00 p.m.

For those not as familiar with Common Core, we will also take some time to watch the presentation of Building The Machine. We will also see a clip or two from the hearings.

If time permits, we will talk about Evan Sayet's to recent Boston appearances. Note he will be returning in the fall.

NOTE: this event is being created by Patrick. Face Book has changed the rules (again) making it impossible to create a FB Public Event for GBTP.

results.description:
Join us for an introduction to this unique Japanese martial art. Participants will all get a chance to practice some basic movements, explore a bit of the underpinning philosophy, and experience seated meditation. In short, we will have fun together learning about this martial way, one unknown to many in the United States. 

Shorinji Kempo is a relatively new martial art. It was founded just after WWII as part of a Zen Buddhist practice. Today, while the martial art has been separated from the religion, the practice of Shorinji Kempo remains true to it's Zen Buddhist roots, with philosophy and meditation still integral to the study in the dojo of hard (punches, kicks and blocks) and soft techniques (releases, joint locks and throws).
results.name: Boston Shorinji Kempo Open Dojo Event

results.description:
(Please note our new RSVP policy below.) 


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us.

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have a large crowd of regulars as well as new members each week.

1. Due to finite space, you must RSVP to attend.


2. Please be considerate of others -- only RSVP if you are likely to attend.

3. If you need to cancel your RSVP, please do so at least 24 hours before the event.  This allows enough notice for someone else to use your spot.

4. Please save loud and/or big games (like those with real-time arguing) for after 9:30, when the room is less full.  This allows us to accommodate more people, and play a greater variety of games.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle


As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (When we have a raffle, you will also receive an extra raffle ticket as thanks for donating.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.



OTHER POLICY DETAILS:

If you would like to come but there are no spots, consider attending our alternative "Light Game Night" a few steps away at Cosi Cafe.  You can also sign up as "wants a spot" and receive emails from meetup if a spot opens up.

We know everyone has emergencies.  But consistent, inconsiderate use of RSVPs -- which includes being a "no show", cancelling in the last 24 hours, or constantly cancelling RSVPs -- will lead to being removed from the group.  Sorry, we still like you, it's just not fair to everyone else!

If you use a "+1" spot, you are responsible for all of the above for your +1.  Since you are using two spots, it is extra important that you are considerate about it.

NEW MEMBERS: Welcome!  We look forward to meeting you.  If you want to bring a friend, please have them sign up with their own account rather than using a +1.  Unfortunately, we've gotten a lot of no-show +1's from first time attendees, so we don't accept those anymore.  Sorry!

results.description:
FEATURE GOES ON EARLY. GET TO THE GALLERY EARLY

Danielle Legros Georges, the current Poet Laureate of the City of Boston, is a professor in the Creative Arts in Learning Division of Lesley University. She also teaches in the Joiner Institute for the Study of War and Social Consequences summer Writer’s Workshop, University of Massachusetts, Boston. Her poems have been widely anthologized, and recent essays of hers have appeared in Others Will Enter the Gates: Immigrant Poets on Poetry, Influences and Writing in America (ed. Abayomi Animashaun) and Anywhere But Here: Black Intellectuals in the Atlantic World and Beyond (eds. Kendahl Radcliffe and Jennifer Scott). She is the author of the volume of poems Maroon. A second book of poems, The Dear Remote Nearness of You, is forthcoming from Barrow Street in 2016.

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are Ladies' Night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Please RSVP if possible; helps everyone to know others are coming.  Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from the cubbies, if available) from 7 - 7:10 PM.  (NOTE: In the rare case the Event Host doesn't arrive within this time window, assume major traffic jam or other catastrophy, ask others nearby to find the group, make introductions, and go climb).  If arriving later, just come find us on the walls.  Hopefully you can recognize us, the Event Host(s) (see RSVP list), from our profile pictures, and/or check the small Whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what we're wearing that day.

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.

For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing. For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Level 1 Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from cubbies, if available).

results.description:
This is a free event at the Willowdale Estate. 

 You must register with Eventbrite to attend.  Please register at the link below:

http://willowdaleestate.com/event/polar-express/

Enjoy and timeless holiday classic with your family presented inside the beautifully decorated estate. With an assortment of delicious movie house refreshments and holiday favorites, will never be one to miss, a tradition in the making. This year we will have a special holiday bell for children at the event and for the first time YOGIBO will sponsor comfortable floor seating for kids and adults of all ages!

The Polar Express (2004) revolves around Billy (Hayden McFarland), who longs to believe in Santa Claus but finds it quite difficult to do so, what with his family’s dogged insistence that all of it, from the North Pole, to the elves, to the man himself, is all just a myth. This all changes, however, on Christmas Eve, when a mysterious train visits Billy in the middle of the night, promising to take him and a group of other lucky children to the North Pole for a visit with Santa. The train’s conductor (Tom Hanks) along with the other passengers help turn Billy’s crisis in faith into a journey of self-discovery. The film is starring Tom Hanks, Directed by Robert Zemeckis, and based on children’s author Chris Van Allsburg’s modern holiday classic of the same name! A long-time fan of Van Allsburg’s book, Hanks also helped produce the

results.description:
This is our brand new auxiliary meetup event.  This is a great opportunity to socialize and play games in a relaxed environment -- and best of all, there's no cap on attendance.

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, but the games at this particular event are going to be on the smaller side -- because those are often the games that work best in a cafe setting.

Our main meetup requires RSVPs due to heavy popularity and finite space.  This event runs simultaneously, two buildings away.  RSVPs are NOT required for this event.  RSVPs are still appreciated so the event hosts know how many people to expect, but you don't need to update them and can come even if you don't RSVP.

This event takes place once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 - 9:30 or 10.  Cosi closes at 10, but after 9:30, you are welcome to come and join the regular meetup at that point, no RSVP required.

Cosi Cafe has graciously allowed us to use their back seating area every week.  You are not required to buy anything from them, but their food is honestly pretty good, so please take advantage of them if you are hungry for dinner, soft drinks, or snacks.

We play whatever people bring, but you don't have to bring anything -- the hosts will always have a bag of games with them!  Some games that you might expect to see here include:

Red 7, Love Letter, Codenames, Pictomania, The Resistance, Avalon, One Night Ultimate Werewolf, Bang!, Glory to Rome, Innovation, Mottainai, Chrononaughts, Time Lines, Tash-Kalar

If you're looking for longer or larger Euros (like 7 Wonders, Puerto Rico, or Terra Mystica), check out our regular "Game Night" meetup.

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs up, then up again towards the busy street, which is Main Street.  Turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it. 
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south. 
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.
