results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

On this call we will share 3 tips to calculate Risk when investing in Discounted Mortgage notes. 

This is what all of the Engineers /Investors have been waiting for    ;-) 

1.Due Diligence

States

State by state listing of foreclosure guidelines

Zillow-How to Automatically grab Zestimates for home & rent, up to 500 addresses per day.

Prices

Max amount to pay for non-performing first notes based on % of BPO, protective equity, and return if you need to foreclose

Arrears

Estimate of late fees from percent or fixed fee or interest, and arrears from number of months late 

2.Strategies with Note

NPV

How to Calculate the NPV = Net Present Value of any payment stream, along with estimate of IRR = Internal Rate of Return

IRR

How to Calculate the best of up to 5 investments based on NPV, IRR, total $ return, cash multiple, and benefit to cost ratio

ROI

How to Calculate  ROI for  defaulted note exit strategy including short sale, loan mod, deed-in-lieu, brokering, and foreclosure

3. Selling the Note

Amort Tbl

A complete amortization table for any of N/I/PV/PMT/FV/PYR

Including balloon payments and/or pre-payment of principal

Including graphs for principal & interest as % of payment

Including graphs for principal & interest cumulative totals

Including summaries by 5-yr totals and calendar year

Including ending balance of $0, also monthly column

Partials

Complete amortization table for both original and partial

Including graph highlighting original and partial payoffs

Including option if you are seller or buyer of partial 

Our goal at NNG is to build a note community by teaching investors how to capitalize on the foreclosure crisis by buying mortgage notes for pennies on the dollar. Purchasing mortgage notes is another alternative to buying foreclosure or owning rental properties.

Take your Note Knowledge to the next level and minimize your risk with education in this alternative investment strategy.

results.description:
December 21, 22 - Ursids Meteor Shower. The Ursids is a minor meteor shower producing about 5-10 meteors per hour. It is produced by dust grains left behind by comet Tuttle, which was first discovered in 1790. The shower runs annually from December 17-25. It peaks this year on the the night of the 21st and morning of the 22nd. This year the waxing gibbous moon will be bright enough to hide most of the fainter meteors. If you are patient, you might still be able to catch some of the brighter ones. Best viewing will be just after midnight from a dark location far away from city lights. Meteors will radiate from the constellation Ursa Minor, but can appear anywhere in the sky.

Source(s):
http://www.seasky.org/astronomy/astronomy-calendar-current.html
results.name: Ursids Meteor Shower

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Tuesday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
Trying to keep this light before the holidays.

Let's reach down inside and pull out our inner child for a night of fun. Please bring some fun games that you may remember playing as a child and have some fun.

We always have a fun nostalgic time at these nights full of childhood memories and fun.

P.S. Grown up games are allowed to be played too, though you may receive glaring and taunting from us kids at hearts!

HOW TO GET THERE

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that C&C members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.
results.name: Return to Childhood Days!

results.description:
Creating Mobile Apps: Native, Hybrid, or Cross Platform Framework?

If you want to create a mobile app targeting the two biggest platforms (iOS and Android), there are choices to make about which development technique to use. This course is aiming to help you make the correct choice by giving an overview and explanation of the three possibilities, and the pros and cons of each in different scenarios.

by Roland Guijt

results.description:
While there's broad agreement that the world will soon sport an Internet of Things consisting of tens of billions of intelligent devices, there's still no consensus on how those devices will connect to each other, to their owner(s) or to the rest of the Internet. Existing wireless technologies, including Bluetooth, WiFi and 3G and 4G cellular networks are ill-suited to large distributed deployments - either because they lack the range and scale required for IoT, or because their processing and power demands are ill suited for use on small, inexpensive and low-power endpoints. 


What's the solution? Who will be the IoT's "Ma Bell"? And - for this group - what features do emerging, distributed IoT network offer to protect the privacy and security of individuals and organizations that rely on them? 

Our December Security of Things MeetUp will delve into these issues and others, featuring presentations by- and discussion with experts from leading commercial firms deploying IoT networks in the U.S. and abroad and groups exploring community-based, open source alternatives to get distributed IoT devices talking. I will update the group with the names of our speakers as soon as I have confirmed them. 

On the agenda for Tuesday evening we have representatives from some of the leading players in IoT networking, including:

Steve Ball, Senet Inc.  Steve is the Senior Director of Project Management at Senet, a provider of Low Power Wide Area Networks (LPWANs).  Senet recently announced the addition of over 2,000 square miles of network coverage for IoT innovators and developers in the Boston metropolitan and suburban areas. Steve will be talking about LPWAN technology, SENET's technology and the work it is doing across verticals with both established and early-stage companies.  

Michael Orr, SIGFOX, Inc. Michael is the Vice President of Partners and Sales, SIGFOX North America. SIGFOX is the world’s leading provider of dedicated cellular connectivity for Internet of Things and machine-to-machine communications. SIGFOX distributed networks are currently operating or being deployed in 12 countries, covering 1 million square kilometers with a population of 165 million people. Five million devices already are registered in the network. 

Robert Mawrey, ioBridge, Inc. Robert is the CEO of ioBridge Inc. Based in Marlborough, ioBridge makes ThingSpeak, an Internet of Things data collection platform. First launched in 2010, ThingSpeak is used to collect, analyze and act on data sent from devices such as Raspberry Pis and Arduinos. Robert will speak about the evolution of the Internet of Things market and the growing role of "Big Data" analysis and algorithms in powering IoT deployments and spurring IoT innovation.  

Thanks once again to our friends at Akamai Technologies for sponsoring our event and to Inex Advisors and CyberSN. We'll be meeting in Akamai's lovely Cambridge headquarters at 150 Broadway in Kendall Square. You will need to have your name on the list to get past the lobby security and up to Akamai's offices, so remember to save your place. 

Once again, we're doing a "ride along" with our friends in the Boston area Internet of Things MeetUp. And once again there will be limited room for attendees, so please RSVP at your earliest convenience. 

I look forward to seeing you there!

- Paul.
results.how_to_find_us: RSVP in advance to get your name on the list to access to Akamai's event room.
results.name: Connecting All The Things: A Discussion of IoT Networks, Security and Identity

results.description:
BostonSpeak's The Professional Speakers Academy & Mastermind is a meetup group for speakers, authors, consultants and other communication professionals who comes together to share experiences, provide feedback, pursue common goals, raise industry standards and improve their businesses by creating more value for the people they serve.


Who Should Attend?

• Individuals who are already involved or will be pursuing a career in speaking.

• Individuals who are committed to constant self-development and have a desire to help others.

• Individuals who are aspiring speakers, professional speakers, NSA members, Toastmasters, communication experts or someone who just loves the art of communication

Why Should You Attend?

Network – Connect with experts and like-minded individuals who are driven to succeed.

Accountability – Gain support and coaching from others to help you keep a commitment.

Learn – Expand your knowledge from presentations about communication and the speaking industry. Share insights and best practices. Feedback – Individual hot seats for you to talk about your challenges and goals.

What is a Mastermind Group? Click Here to Learn More

Agenda:

6:30pm - Introductions

6:40pm - Catherine Storing - Five Insider Tips to Up Your Speaking Game

6:50pm - Breakout session (Mastermind Session)

7:20pm- Kit Pang - The Art of Impromptu Speaking

7:30pm - Breakout session (Mastermind Session)

7:55pm - Wrap up

Presenter Bios:

Catherine Storing (www.StylingFaith.com)

FASHION STYLIST | PERSONAL SHOPPER | BEST SELLING AUTHOR | SPEAKER | STYLE COACH | VIRTUAL STYLIST | FAITHPRENEUR |

Catherine was born and raised in the Dominican Republic, land of beautiful beaches, friendly people and gorgeous women with dangerous curves. However, she did not fit it, her hair was too curly, her legs too lanky and her mouth too big and opinionated. Every day she wished to be accepted as she was despite of not looking like a typical Dominican woman. Catherine’s journey of self-discovery not only gave her the ability to see beauty in others but to also to guide others through the process of finding their own beauty and strength.

Kit Pang (www.kitpang.com)

Kit Pang is a public speaking consultant and trainer. He loves to work with entrepreneurs to hone their storytelling skills while offering engaging and insightful experiences through communication seminars for organizations.

Currently, he is the President of the Federal Toastmaster Club of Boston and a member of the Advanced Access Toastmaster Club in Brookline. Kit is a TEDx Speaker Coach and the founder of BostonSpeaks, a Meetup group dedicated to connecting speakers in Boston. Kit has won numerous awards in public speaking and actively participates in story slams and poetry slams throughout Boston

results.description:
Calvin Trillin, the celebrated New Yorker writer, offers a rich and engaging biography of his father, as well as a literate and entertaining fanfare for the common (and decent, and hard-working) man.

Abe Trillin had the western Missouri accent of someone who had grown up in St. Joseph and the dreams of America of someone who had been born is Russia. In Kansas City, he was a grocer, at least until he swore off the grocery business. He was given to swearing off things―coffee, tobacco, alcohol, all neckties that were not yellow in color. Presumably he had also sworn off swearing, although he was a collector of curses, such as "May you have an injury that is not covered by workman's compensation." Although he had a strong vision of the sort of person he wanted his son to be, his explicit advice about how to behave didn't go beyond an almost lackadaisical "You might as well be a mensch." Somehow, though, Abe Trillin's messages got through clearly.

The author's unerring sense of the American character is everywhere apparent in this quietly powerful memoir.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be in the front of the cafe near the windows.
results.name: Messages from My Father: A Memoir

results.description:
This is one of the meetings of the study group for Principles of Synthetic Biology edX course https://www.edx.org/course/principles-synthetic-biology-mitx-20-305x

edX published a set of background modules for the course. It includes a module about ordinary differential equations. Which probable will be the hardest part for many people.


So we will meet and go over basic math concepts needed for the course. We will try to build an intuitive understanding of functions, derivatives, integrals, and differential equations.

The aim is not to learn how to take derivatives or solve differential equations. Software will do that for us. Instead we will try to understand how we suppose to apply them to real-life problems.
results.name: Study group: Principles of Synthetic Biology - Math Bootcamp

Hello Fellow Earth Citizens!

We all want more energy, right?  It affects our mood, productivity and state of mind, not to mention others around us. 

The foundation of the Earth Citizen Movement is healing yourself. If you are happy and healthy you can help others and the earth with joy.  So what does energy have to do with your health?

Find out in this fun and informative session.  We'll talk about meditation and do some stretching and breathing exercises together.  We'll end with a special trick to feel your own energy.  

How can you help the earth? Help yourself first! And start right here :). 

This event is free! You can bring a friend but limited spots available, please RSVP online.

We start off chatting about our work, including setting goals for ourselves (which is entirely optional but super helpful!), and then we write. That's what it's all about. As simple as the idea is, it's amazing how much more you can get done simply by being in the presence of other writers at work. The baked goods don't hurt, either.


There is power for laptops, and some of us use pen and paper. Your choice! Bonus: there's no Internet access, so you can omit a huge distraction without even trying. And, although we are not a discussion group, there are many areas where people can go if they want to talk without being disruptive.

Please click here for detailed directions! The school can be a bit of a maze and I don't want anybody getting lost.

Spend some time on your project by bringing it along to our weekly project night, an evening designed around you and what you're working on.

This weekly event is about finding time to tinker, being creative, and meeting other members of the community.  You'll get the chance to see what others are working on, share your projects, and to get inspiration and feedback from fellow tinkerers.

On any given Tuesday night you have people working on electronics, knitting, writing code, wood-working, or just their plans for world domination. Beer is also consumed.

We’ll provide: space to work, basic tools, power, a room full of like minded people.

You’ll provide: your project, ideas and beer. A laptop would probably be useful too.

Sometimes we work on group projects together, which are usually set up as separate meetup events. Keep an eye on our events page to see what we’re working on next.

Find us: http://p.irateship.com/treasuremap.html

This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.

Curious as to the Buddhist impact on the west? Interested in why this may be so?
Care to consider the views and experiences of others?

Buddhist Reflections is an informal, no-sectarian gathering open to all. Meeting monthly to examine, discuss and share themes relating to Buddhist history, philosophy, interpretations and opinions.

Our goals include discussing:
The Buddhist "Way".
Comparing Buddhism to other philosophies
Examining interpretations of Buddhist writings, both historical and contemporary
Investigating how Buddhist thought may be brought into our daily lives. Join us for 90 minutes of investigation, exchanging ideas and considering how the teaching of Buddhism may serve us as we live in the present and going forward.

Prior to the Zen Center program at 7 PM is the Buddha' Belly Book Discussion Group at 6 PM.  The group will be reading and discussing Dan Goleman's new book, A Force for Good: The Dalai Lama's Vision for Our World.  OutBreathren who are interested are warmly invited to join the book discussion at 6.

Though not exclusively LGBTQ, this is a super LGBTQ-friendly event. The teacher/facilitator is ASC Senior Minister & uber-awesome lesbian, Rev. Kim K. Crawford Harvie. Rev. Crawford Harvie was previously minister of the UU Meeting House in Provincetown where she was named Provincetown Citizen of the Year. She teaches in the Zen Buddhist tradition.

results.description:
Following the great success of our well attended and enjoyable critique night we are offering it again!

bring along up to three images on a thumb drive or CD/DVD and have them anonymously and constructively  critiqued by Ian and the group.

Having your images critiqued is a great way to improve your photography.  Knowing how others see your wonderful images can be very informative and challenging. The anonymity of this process ensures that you will not feel embarrassed, and of course if the image receives rave reviews you can always claim it as yours :-)

Just as important as having your images critiqued is learning how to look at and critique the images of others. 

The session will run from 7.30pm until 10pm and is just $25 (but there is a limit on numbers so RSVPing is essential.
results.how_to_find_us: Enter through the EMT Training Center door and head to the second floor
results.name: Image Critique Night

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.
results.how_to_find_us: Once up the stairs, turn around to your left, and go in the door that is mostly glass panes
results.name: Mindfulness Meditation

This week's show will have a special holiday feel.

Hosted by Shawn Carter (Fart the Podcast)

"War on Christmas" Painting by Kerrie Marks.

The show is always hilarious and it attracts the best and brightest young comedians in Boston as well as an exceptionally clever audience. While we already have a great group of regulars that come to this show each week we're always happy to meet more people that enjoy comedy.

The stand up show runs from 8-10 Before the show there is a writer's workshop for any aspiring comedians. 6:30.

results.description:
Come meditate with us every Tuesday and Friday at 8pm in our beautiful public meditation center. We offer a short (10 minute) introductory talk about a Buddhist topic and conclude with a half hour meditation session. Meditation is always free and guided in English. Everyone is welcome to come and explore their minds highest potential!

Street parking is available on the corner of Rockingham and Granite street and along Granite.  There is also a large parking lot with a Trader Joe's 2 minutes walk away from the center.

Cambridge, MA 02139

results.description:
We are meeting every Tuesday night from 8:00 PM to 10:00 PM practicing Modern Arnis, WC, and SCJ flow drills and Self-Defense skills.

All levels are welcome!  For ages 15 and up.


The price is $15.00 /per person /per meetup or  $50.00 per month. The first meetup is free.

Please wear loose fitting, comfortable cloths suitable for working out.

Please do not wear shoes that you've worn outdoors on the wood floor.

Instructor's Background

Alix Lavaud has been training Martial Arts for over 45 years and is a master of Modern Arnis, Pien San Wing Chun Kung Fu, and has extensive training in Small Circle Jujitsu.  He also humbly owns the rank of Lakan Apat (a 4th degree BLACKBELT ).


Lineage

Modern Arnis :  Remy Presas  -->  Alix Lavaud

Wing Chun:  Henry Mui  -->  Alix Lavaud

Small Circle Jujitsu:  Wally Jay -->  Alix Lavaud


Philosophy

 Go With The Flow ...

Some Quotes we Love

“If your mind is empty, it is ready for anything. In the beginner’s mind there are many possibilities, but in the expert’s there are few”
― Shunryu Suzuki


“Everything is perfect and there is always room for improvement.”
― Shunryu Suzuki

“We must exist right here and right now!”
― Shunryu Suzuki

Benefits of Martial Arts

1.  Mental Benefits

2.  Improved Balance

3.  Improved Flexibility

4.  Focus and stillness

5.  Hand and Eye Coordination

6.  Improved reflexes

7.  Learn self-defense skills

8.  Stress relief

9.  Relax

10.  Gain Self Confident and Self Respect

11.  Learn to Breathe

12.  Learn to Find Focus and Stillness

13.  Encouraging Non-Violent Conflict Resolution

14.  Improvement in many other Areas of Life
results.how_to_find_us: Studio is UPSTAIRS from McGill's convenience store, all parking is on the street.  Zoom Zone is located in the former Dance Track and TKO boxing space, next to Billy's Roast Beef.
results.name: Tuesday Nights:  Modern Arnis - Wing Chun - Small Circle Jujitsu Training

We will be playing indoors at the Mansfield Sports Plex (31 Oxford Rd, Mansfield, MA).  They have both courts and a turf field.  We can use cleats, sneakers, or indoor soccer shoes on the turf field, but only sneakers/indoor soccer shoes on the courts.  

Come prepared to play on either surface because if we get too many for the turf, we'll have to split into two games (one on turf and the other on the courts).

Cost should be about $10 per person.

Also bring both a white and dark shirt to help split into teams.

We are joining another group of players, so there should be enough to play even if there aren't many RSVPs.

Thanks,

-Dave

results.description:
We've all heard it before from a seller: "I want to sell my house, but I don't want to put it on the market" I'm willing to compensate you but I don't want to go through the hassle of selling." We've had this happen to us dozens of times in the past couple of years and at one point we chalked these ones up as "dead leads". However, in the past year, we've developed a system internally to sell these houses completely off market. It is of course more work, but offers a much better alternative to walking away from a deal. In this week's marketing meeting we will cover:

1. What is an off market open house?
2. Why would you want to do it?
3. How we do it
4. When to do it
results.name: How To Sell A Property Off Market

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Wednesday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
Ok, you're right. It is all about me. If you want to choose the exhibits, you can organize your own event.


Let's meet at 2:00 and browse some of the exhibitions at the MFA, and stroll through the galleries. at 3:00, we'll take the Arts of the Americas tours, that will last til 4:00 - the museum is open until 9:45 so you'll have a chance to see the exhibits you wish to see, also. Here's what I'd like to see:

Class Distinctions 
Dutch Painting in the Age of Rembrandt and Vermeer

(I've seen this before, and it's definitely worth seeing again)

http://www.mfa.org/exhibitions/class-distinctions

</a>Marilyn Arsem 
100 Ways to Consider Time <a href="http://www.mfa.org/exhibitions/marilyn-arsem">http://www.mfa.org/exhibitions/marilyn-arsem 

Gold and the Gods 
Jewels of Ancient Nubia http://www.mfa.org/exhibitions/gold-and-gods I encourage you to support the museum, and buying a membership is an excellent way to do so -- you can get into all the Friday night social events, and also go to most other museum functions, and gain free admission any day the museum is open. What a bargain!! Some memberships start to pay for themselves after three admissions.

Regular adult admission is $25, but you may also be able to borrow passes from your local library.

Let's meet in the lobby, in front of the statue of Orpheus and Cerberus, and let's go see the exhibitions that I want to see. Of course, this is still a free country, pending the results of the election, and you can also look at some of the exhibitions you would like to see. I won't stop you.
results.how_to_find_us: i will send out instructions to those who sign up.
results.name: MFA - Art of the Americas Tour + see the exhibits Ron wants to see

results.description:
Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 


Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill
Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street
Mission Hill, Roxbury
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops)
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer,
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"!
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).


We arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Tobin Community Center 
1481 Tremont Street, Boston, MA

THERE IS NO PARKING - IT'S BEST FOR THOSE WHO LIVE IN BOSTON AND TRAVEL IN ON THE MBTA

THERE IS NO PARKING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

Every Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Bring friends!  Forward the invitation to others!

Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share'
buttons
http://www.yelp.com/events/boston-volunteering-for-2-bag-of-produce-in-mission-hill-each-wednesday-afternoon-from-4-6-pm-at-tobin-community-center

Looking for an ARTIST to help VISUALLY REPRESENT this vegetable outreach effort. 
TALK with us FIRST !!

Looking for Gifted Marketers to 
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and 
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Vegan Cooking classes or Vegan Cooking Ideas

Vegan Cooking Classes or  
Learning How to Prepare Vegan Food
(using the $2 bag of produce as a low-cost start) 


What Can You Do With Your $2 Bag?

Portion Control

Bake...Don't Fry!

Roasted Veggie Stackers

No-Guilt Banana Ice Cream

Avocados!!!

Salad with Chipotle Hummus

Simple Cilantro Chutney

More $2 bags of Produce!

Drink your greens!

results.description:
Let's enjoy the fun festive Boston Pops "Holiday Pops" Concert at Symphony Hall!

This is an Annual Tradition. If you've always wanted to attend--this is your chance. 

Join the Boston Pops and conductor Keith Lockhart, celebrating his 20th anniversary with the orchestra, in a performance filled with holiday music favorites, the traditional Pops sing-a-long, and even a visit from jolly old Santa Claus. 

**Tix start from $31. You must buy your ticket on your own. To buy Tix see www.BSO.org  or Tel:[masked]

results.description:
Come join us for a midweek climb!


All levels are welcome! If you are new to climbing, there is a belay class at 7 PM. Here is the link to sign up: www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown 

I will happily belay those who have not climbed before up until 7 PM, but then it's really important to know how to belay and to take the belay test that starts at 7 PM. You can rejoin the group after taking the belay test.

For those of you who already know how to belay, no need to take the class, you just need to pass this gym's belay test when you arrive.

The price is as follows:

Membership: $89/month

Adult Day Pass: $22 

Gear (shoes, harness, belay device): $8 ($5 for members)

Belay class: $15 (free for members)

Belay test: Free

We will meet at the cluster of cubbies on the first floor at 6:30 PM, greet each other, make sure everyone has a group or person to climb with then head off to climb. I'm looking into whether there is a place nearby to grab a bite or drink at the end of the night. If you have a place in mind, please let me know.

I'll send a message letting you know what color shirt and pants I am wearing incase you arrive late and want to search for us. I will also swing by the cubbies every 15 minutes until everyone who signed up has arrived. So, if you are not able to make it or are running late, PLEASE COMMUNICATE on this event's chat or by contacting my cell-phone, which I will send out once you are confirmed for the event.

Hope you can make it! I'm looking forward to meeting more climbers in the area.

~Avery~
results.how_to_find_us: Will meet at 6:30 PM at the cubbies by the stairs

results.description:
Morning Star Sangha is a Boundless Way Zen practice group. We heartily welcome all practitioners. We meet Wednesday evenings from 7:00-8:30 PM at St. John's Episcopal Church, 297 Lowell Avenue, Newton, MA. Plenty of street parking is available. We enter the church through the red doors along Otis Street.  You are welcome to join us on any Wednesday evening, as your schedule allows. 


Our practice includes a liturgy service, 25 minute sitting periods, walking meditation, dharma talks, discussions, and personal meditation instruction in private interviews with a teacher. Talks and interviews will be offered by our practice leader, Boundless Way Zen Priest and Senior Dharma Teacher Michael Fieleke, and by visiting Boundless Way Zen teachers.

Morning Star Sangha is a community of Zen practitioners in the lineage of Boundless Way Zen, a school which combines Japanese Soto and Korean Rinzai traditions in innovative ways that include basic meditation practices such as breath awareness, mindfulness practices, inquiry into the moment, shikantaza (just sitting), and koan practice in the Harada-Yasutani tradition. 

If it is your first time sitting with a Boundless Way Zen group, please arrive 15 minutes early for an orientation, and please email [masked]. 

Check out our website at <a>https://morningstarsangha.wordpress.com.</a>;
results.name: Zen Meditation

results.description: "I appeal to you, brothers, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that all of you agree, and that there be no divisions among you, but that you be united in the same mind and the same judgment."  Perhaps one of the most troubled churches we see in the New Testament while also being one of the most blessed, Corinth is an example of God's grace not to give up on a struggling church, as well as an example of how to be the church God wants.  1 (and 2!) Corinthians, Paul's back-to-back letters to the saints in Corinth, provide great insight into unity, maturity, church growth, humility, love, the resurrection, church discipline, salvation, faith, and a number of essential topics for those seeking God.  Come join us in our study of 1 Corinthians!

results.description:
At 7 pm we will order supper on individual bills. The talk won't begin till after supper, about 8 pm.  A wireless mike and speakers will be available. People are welcome to gather earlier than 7 pm for conversation. --Murray E. Denofsky


In the 1960s many computer scientists predicted that in a couple decades computers would be able to do anything human minds could do. Led by the Department of Defense, specialized expert systems were developed that efficiently answered spoken questions in specific fields. Now research is refocusing on the original goal of artificial general intelligence that may develop into superintelligence.

Advances in technology, especially IT, are accelerating toward the singularity when machine intelligence can improve itself far better than any humans can. Superintelligent machines may then work toward restoring paradise earth or exterminating humans infesting it. Or civilization may well collapse long before the singularity.

The talk will present a summary of recent advances and their potential for good and evil. I’ll present an infographic on the subject and hope to learn more from members who know much that I don’t. Topics may include:

AI history and bottlenecks: Early optimism led to research splitting into various teams that communicated little with each other.

Possible applications: research, product development and marketing, language translation, speech recognition in any language and accent, tutoring, consumer product selection, cancer treatment by big pharma, warrior drones and robots to kill thousands, ideal partners for humans, reforming politics and ending war

Advanced technologies: The current shrinking of transistors is approaching its limit. Further progress depends on new technologies like carbon nanotube transistors, quantum computing, inexact computing, and cognitive computing that learns from interaction with humans and its environment

Intelligent personal assistants: perform tasks for an individual based on user input, location awareness, and access to information online such as weather, traffic, user schedules. Examples of such an agent are Apple's Siri, Google's Google Now, Amazon Echo, Microsoft's Cortana, Braina, Samsung's S Voice, LG's Voice Mate, SILVIA, HTC's Hidi, IBM's Watson, and Facebook's M.

Smart personal agents: perform ongoing tasks such as schedule management and restaurant reservation changes autonomously.

Cognitive computing such as IBM Watson: Understands natural language, extracts information from unstructured documents, and provides best rated answers. In 2011 Watson soundly beat the best human players at Jeopardy, and now has shrunk to the size of a desktop PC and its services are offered on free trial to consumers and businesses.

Dangers of Super AI: Depending on who first develops it, whether military, foreign powers, academia, or fastbuck corporations, results will vary. Presently 50 nations are developing AI warrior robots that may become stronger, faster and smarter than humans, able to swarm through a city, break down doors, and kill all who are judged dangerous, a Dick Cheney dream. Super AI may decide that humans are so warlike and mentally ill that to save AI and the planet, they must be exterminated by nuclear weapons, a power grid meltdown, or a virus pandemic.

Stages of AI: Superintelligence will grow in 4 phases:

1. Humans improve it until phase 2

2. Recursive Self-Improvement, better at designing itself than humans can, could do social manipulation and hacking, could be stopped if it causes trouble

3. Covert preparation, strategizing for long term goals

4. Overt implementation, can make heaven or hell on earth

Other: Transhumanism means humans and computers joined into cyborgs; the rights and responsibilities of human-smart robots and their programmers; downloading a human brain; Ray Kurzweil predicts desktop computers will equal human processing power in 2029, the singularity in 2045

by Robin Harper. I've:

• been with the group from the start

• been an early adopter of IT since 1981

• learned to write using many kinds of information structures, not just pictures & paragraphs as in most books and websites


• identified human instincts that evolved for survival & empire building, yet threaten our existence as a species
results.name: Artificial general intelligence: savior, slayer, or not happening

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.how_to_find_us: The third table in the middle of the climbing area between 7:00-7:10 PM. It's the table in the middle of the TR \/ Lead area.

results.description:
Christmas is the holiday which Christians use to celebrate the birth of Jesus.   The day John describes as being when, "the logos became flesh and made his dwelling among us" (John 1:14), referring to Jesus. 

What does it mean to believe in incarnation?  The earliest Christians wrote that Jesus was the "image of the invisible God," the "logos" (or revelation) of God, and "the Way to the Father."  Almost all in the Jewish tradition had been hoping for a Messiah, and some in first century came to believe that Jesus was their fulfilled hope.  

Ancient Greeks believed that the gods regularly procreated with humans making demigods.  Hindus believe that there have been multiple emanations (or avatars) of the divine Vishnu (including Jesus).  So this idea of incarnation has gotten some play throughout the world and in history.  

What are the different ways to believe in incarnation, and what are some reasons (and/or consequences) to believing or disbelieving in it? 

Hope you can make it!  Happy Holidays!
results.how_to_find_us: we'll be in the booths at the back
results.name: Belief(s) in (the) incarnation?

results.description:
PLEASE NOTE: In anticipation of the Glass-Chewing Leader of the Cartel's imminent absence due to Family Growth, hosting duties for the regular Wednesday Night Gaming is being handled by a rotating cast of regulars.

Wednesday Night Gaming is our more-or-less weekly free-for-all of strategy gaming goodness downstairs at the Porter Square Panera. There's rarely a set agenda for these events but you are welcome and encouraged to hash out a plan beforehand in comments if you've got something you're dying to play. Nonetheless, you are not required to bring a game to play -- our only requirement is that you bring an open mind!

The event officially begins at 7 PM but people often trickle in early, so you're welcome to sit down to a filler game to get warmed up, or arrange to meet a little early if you've got a group looking to tackle an extra-meaty game.

Please be aware that Panera has been quite gracious about hosting us with minimal fuss -- in order to keep things this way, please respect the hardworking people who work there and, especially, their desire to get out after a long shift.

We'll see you at the gaming table!
results.name: Wednesday Gaming In Porter Square

results.description:
Here are just some of the things you can get out of these meetings:

• Access to thousands of dollars of courses, software, and other resources

• Advice on overcoming a business or marketing obstacle you're facing

• Accountability

• Ideas and inspiration

• Meet awesome people who enjoy talking about this stuff as much as you do

Or, you can be a fly on the wall.  No pressure at all.  Feel free to drop in to just listen and see what internet marketing really looks like from people who are actually doing it.

We try to keep the meetings to about 60 - 90 minutes.  Here's the way it works:

• 7:00pm Join the meeting here:  https://hangouts.google.com/call/dq4qhhdefftaq3fmqwij2ipe2ea.  It tends to work best with Chrome (rather than Internet Explorer or FireFox).

• Intros, and goal checking:

• New Members:  What are you working on?  And what is it you hope to get out of attending these meetings?

• Existing Members:  How'd your week go?  Did you accomplish your goals?  What are your goals for next week.

• Check-Up on last week's Couch of Insight participate:  What results did he/she get from the session?

• The Couch of Insight:  One member goes into depth on what they've been working on, telling us where they need assistance, what resources have helped them to be successful, and what strategies have been valuable.

• (Meeting Ends around 8pm officially, but usually runs late with people wanting to help the person on The Couch.)

• Chat and Offer Assistance: The Hangout will remain open until everyone leaves.  You can stay as long as you want to meet new members and give the person on The Couch any advice or feedback you may have.

Feedback

What's ONE thing that would have made this meeting better? Either let me know during the session, or you can keep it anonymous by filling out the a Survey Monkey (I'll provide the link in the session).

<a href="https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/KFNMRFX"></a>
results.how_to_find_us: Google Hangouts.  Join by clicking the link in the description.  Give it a shot before the meeting to make sure you can join without any problems.  Let me know if you're having trouble.

Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

When: 7 pm, December 24th, 2015

I am not christian, I am not religious, and I do not believe in God but I think that Albanian religious institutions in the United States are a lot more than just religious institutions; they are Albanian institutions. I have noticed over the 15 years I have lived in United States Albanian churches and mosques have worked hard to bring the Albanian community together.  From the days of Gjergj Kastrioti to Euro 2016, history has shown than when united, Albanians can be very successful.

I have much to be thankful, and grateful for! Our own Liz admins this cause. Connecting the dots, trying to make a difference. The youth today will shape the world, and they need our support. Help if you can. RSVP if you support the cause. Thanks. 

Dear Friend,

As a former teacher, I know how hard it can be to get the classroom supplies needed to help students learn and succeed.  School budgets are shrinking and teachers are using their own money to purchase the supplies they need just to do their job.  At this time of year, many teachers are running out of supplies, and facing the need to re-stock their classrooms for the new semester.
  So I want to thank you for your past support of AdoptAClassroom.org, and ask you to please join me this holiday season by adopting one or more teachers to help us reach our goal of 3,000 new teacher adoptions by year-end.  If we do this together, we will help more than 75,000 students in classrooms across the country.

</a> <a href="http://adoptaclassroom.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=190d6057b66dd311cc99c3e8e&id=c639a24929&e=c2d10a6e9a">

To make an even bigger impact, please consider a year end contribution to 

AdoptAClassroom.org’s Annual Fund

. This fund supports AdoptAClassroom.org’s operations, and helps them continue the great work they are doing by reaching more teachers and more students.

Supporting teachers is a cause that is near to my family and my heart. This holiday season, let’s open our hearts to support classrooms in need across the nation.

Sincerely,

Sheryl Crow


National Spokesperson for AdoptAClassroom.org

Help us support thousands of classrooms across the nation.

results.description:
By signing up and/or attending a Boston Area Photography Group meetup you agree to the Boston Area Photography Group Disclaimer below.

No guests are permitted on Boston Area Photography Group events. Please have your guests join our Meetup. 

MEETUP DESCRIPTION:

Lets capture the rare Full Cold Moon. It is rare for the cold full moon to fall on Christmas.  The last one was in 1977... before a significant portion of our membership was born.... the next will be in 2034. The term cold moon refers to its placement in the calendar as the first full moon of the winter.

Peak viewing will occur at 6:11a.

Sunrise at 7:18a

Moon set at 7:02a

GEAR/CLOTHING/FOOTWARE SUGGESTIONS: Tripod and long lense

Remember: we are volunteers. You are responsible for your own safety and enjoyment.

Parking: There is Street Parking in front of the Church (double lane when there is a Church Event)

results.name: Christmas Celebration at St. George Albanian Cathedral in Boston.

results.description:
The plan is to meet at the Hei La moon Restaurant in Chinatown for dim sum. Afterwards we will start our walk in Chinatown and then head towards the Rose Kennedy Greenway, Aquarium, and then make a loop back, (about a 2-3 mile walk). Note; walking part is weather dependent.  For the Restaurant meal, figure about up to, or around $20 per person, depending on what is ordered).

Please bring small bills to make for easy change, if possible

On street parking: the City of Boston parking meters are free on legal holidays and no time limit is enforced.

Via MBTA:  Take the Orange line to the Chinatown stop.

We will  meet at 10:45 am inside the entrance to the Restaurant on the first floor for an 11:00 am seating. I will have a folder with me that says Boston Walking on it.
results.name: Dim Sum and then some.. Hei La moon, Chinatown

venue.name: Intersection of Huron and Aberdeen Ave, Fresh Pond side of the street

results.description:
F=\Walk off all that extra food!


this is on, rain or shine or snow. See you there.

We'll do two laps, approximately five miles.

Few things relieve stress better than a some exercise on a nice winter evening.

Let's join some local walking groups for a stroll in a beautiful setting.

If you've still got some energy left, we'll be heading to Mt. Auburn Cemetery, then out to lunch at a local eatery. Parking on Huron Avenue is easy, since the "Permit Parking" rules don't apply on Sunday - just park in any spot on Huron Ave, there will be plenty of them.

If you're coming by bus, take the 71 or 73 bus from Harvard Square and get off at Aberdeen Ave. Walk all the way up Aberdeen until you come to Huron Avenue, we'll be there.

If you have trouble finding us, call me at[masked]
results.name: Christmas Day walk around Fresh Pond and maybe Mt. Auburn Cemetery, too.

results.description: We can meet at the movie theater 12:00 pm.  People can choose a movie that ideally begins between 12:20 pm and 1:45 pm.  Movies cost $10.  After the movie we will eat at Bamboos which is across the street next to it.  Meet at 4:30 pm.  RSVP for dinner by December 18.
results.how_to_find_us: I will be wearing a Mosaic Hat.  We will meet near the chairs near the escalator.

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
